movie_review_blurb: Presents a chain of breathtaking images that showcases the Cirque's artists from a unique point of view.

movie_review_blurb: For sheer inventiveness of situation and the charm that such an idea projects, The Love Bug rates as one of the better entries of the Disney organization.

One of those ambitious, over-reaching disappointments that is more interesting than some more conservative successes.
The product of a feverish, overflowing imagination, this almost impossibly dense take on The Tempest displays both the director's audacious brilliance and lewd extravagance at full tilt.
Performances all fall in a middle range between the competent and the lackluster.
A drab actionless story of ungodly length and apparently telling nothing.
Graceless and only intermittently lit up by lunacy and satire.

Both overall director Richard Fleischer and his Japanese counterparts do a dull job, and the monotonously low-key tone of scene after scene almost suggests that each was filmed without a sense of ultimate slotting in the finished form.
It's an unusual picture shot against authentic Hong Kong backgrounds and offbeat in its treatment, yet as simple and moving a love story as has come along in many a moon.
movie_title: Love Is a Many Splendored Thing (1955)

movie_review_blurb: The color, the sets, the expanse and the imaginative quality of the filming are unexcelled.
movie_title: Henry V (The Chronicle History of King Henry the Fift with His Battell Fought at Agincourt in France) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: A tense, melodramatic story, clearly presented, and excellently acted by one of the finest casts assembled for a film.
John Cassavetes' first Hollywood-made project shows a tendency to force casebook psychology on the characters at a loss of spontaneity.
A strange, brooding tale.
movie_title: Il portiere di notte (The Night Porter) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: The Turning Point is one of the best films of its era.
The Servant is for the most part strong dramatic fare, though the atmosphere and tension is not fully sustained to the end.

It's Americana, and a document of its time as well via observation of audiences and the life surrounding the Newport event, not least the neatly-integrated footage concerning the America Cup Yacht Races.
Trite and often ponderous in its philosophizing by the two principals.
Well crafted, finely acted, and conjures up a positively intriguing milieu.
Brittle Chandler characters have been transferred to the screen with punch by Howard Hawks' production and direction, providing full load of rough, tense action most of the way.
Although it is more of a comedy of manners than a well-developed story, there are enough yocks and bright moments to make it a thoroughly enjoyable outing.
movie_title: Down and Out in Beverly Hills (1986)

movie_review_blurb: Lassie emerges as nice entertainment enhanced by color photography and good scenic shots.
James Hill's production, locationed in Manhattan, captures the feel of Broadway and environs after dark.
Basil Radford gives a flawless performance.
A touching and universal love story.
Their romance is enhanced by Nestor Almendros' exquisite photography (and Basil Poledouris' score), as is the stunning beauty of the Fiji island where it was filmed.
Although the film is punched up by some energetic cutting and hip-hop music, many dialogue scenes, particularly early on, are badly written and awkwardly staged.
movie_title: Just Another Girl on the I.R.T. (1993)

Uncompelling but moderately engaging.
[The film] has plenty of absorbing characters, smart, snappy dialog and delightful stretches of comic foolery.

Direction by Mitchell Leisen is generally satisfactory, although picture is slow in getting under way and has several spots that could be tightened.
Casting is meticulously perfect to make every character a caricature of itself.
Peter Sellers has some amusing gags as the gambler, the chance of dressing up in various guises and a neat near-seduction scene with Ursula Andress.
...another bittersweet comedy commentary on contemporary US mores.
Wilder, usually a director of considerable flair and inventiveness -- has not been able this time out to rise above a basically vulgar, as well as creatively delinquent, screenplay...
The screenplay, based on a one-act play by Ferenc Molnar, is outstanding.
Most of the time, it's up to director Wilder to sustain a two-hour-plus film on treatment alone, a feat he manages to accomplish more often than not, and sometimes the results are amazing.
Pictures like this, with a sense of humor that is as broad as it can be sophisticated, come along only infrequently.
Easter Parade is a musical with old and new Irving Berlin tunes and standout dance numbers.
Spirit is a James Stewart one-man show.
What counts is that laughs come thick and fast, that the general entertainment is light and gay.
That the climax fizzles must be laid on doorstep of Halsted Welles, who adapts Elmore Leonard's story quite well until that point.
This uninspired version amounts to lukewarm sloppy seconds in comparison to the original film that made director John Carpenter a hot property.
Fourth entry in the Halloween horror series is a no-frills, workmanlike picture.
movie_title: Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers (1988)

movie_review_blurb: After a promising opening, Halloween becomes just another maniac-on-the-loose suspenser.

This start for Gregory as producer and Laughton as director is rich in promise but the completed product, bewitching at times, loses sustained drive via too many offbeat touches that have a misty effect.

A period story about a small northwest mountain village where stars Warren Beatty and Julie Christie run the bordello, the production suffers from overlength; also a serious effort at moody photography which backfires into pretentiousness.
Somewhere in the telling, the original premise of the Mari Sandoz novel is lost sight of in a wholesale insertion of extraneous incidents which bear little or no relation to the subject.
Cleopatra is not only a supercolossal eye-filler (the unprecedented budget shows in the physical opulence throughout), but it is also a remarkably literate cinematic recreation of an historic epoch.
Let It Be is a relatively innocuous, unimaginative piece of film.
Here are all the ingredients of a novel entertainment.
A totally bubblegum and cotton candy melange of garish fantasy and narcissism.
movie_title: Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (1978)

movie_review_blurb: The incidents are often outrageously irreverent. The comedy is fast and furious, both sophisticated and sophomoric.

movie_title: The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes (1970)

movie_review_blurb: A lusty comedy-melodrama, loaded with bold, masculine humor and as much of the original's uninhibited earthiness as good taste and the Production Code permit.

Multiple functions of Charles Brackett and Billy Wilder on Waltz have given film an infectious quality that surmounts the gorgeously apt trappings against which is projected the fable of an American travelling phonograph salesman.
Director Billy Wilder handles the varied story elements, countless suspenseful moments and vivid portrayals in excellent fashion.
Vitti once again proves an ideal performer for Antonioni's thematics in what is probably her best role to date.

There may be some meaning, some commentary about life being a game, beyond what remains locked in the mind of film's creator, Italian director-writer Michelangelo Antonioni. But it is doubtful that the general public will get the 'message' of this film.
Antonioni has sought to bring into the focus of his own insights, the student vs establishment conflict. He is on foreign terrain.

A sumptuously produced period piece that is also a rich tapestry of childhood memoirs and moods, fear and fancy, employing all the manners and means of the best of cinematic theatrical from high and low comedy to darkest tragedy.
The Serpent's Egg lacks both the strength and depth of Bergman's major work. By going outwardly international, the master becomes perilously close to becoming shallow as well.
Ingmar Bergman's dark vision of the human condition has focused on individuals incapable of real inter-personal communications except on the most primitive level.
There is not much dialogue, almost no music, but the sex scenes have vigor and primitive power, to say the least.
Not a pleasant film, it is a great one.
movie_title: Såsom i en Spegel (Through A Glass Darkly) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Lagging direction, so-so thesping and usual femme and lowdown aspects of this type production make this an ordinary entry.
As a dance flick, Shag suffers from an unexciting dance-style and so-so choreography but compensates with a fine young cast and likable story.
Writer-director Paul Brickman can therefore be accused of trying to have it both ways, but there's no denying the stylishness and talent of his direction.

Despite some funny scenes, the sitcomish treatment of a father's anxiety over his teenage daughter's budding sexuality is mostly shallow and uneven.
Expectations that Eddie Murphy's street brand of rebelliousness would devastate staid and glittery Beverly Hills are not entirely met in a film that grows increasingly dramatic.
The result is repetitive and precious rather than inventive and fresh.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: Schematic and unconvincing.

Despite the fact that picture runs 118 minutes, Frank Capra has expanded on the original play [by Joseph Kesselring] to a sufficient extent to maintain a steady, consistent pace.

A strikingly dramatic, realistic and provocatively topical film.
Although this has a few hallucinating bits of terror, the film is primarily a creaky-door type of melodrama.
MacMurray has seldom given a better performance. It is somewhat different from his usually light roles, but is always plausible and played with considerable restraint.

A sparkling and effervescing piece of farce-comedy.
Much of the pic's peculiar fascination comes from tangential scenes, limning each character's odd obsession, be it food, girls, soccer, or just watching the traffic drive by.
Set in 1969 England, it portrays the last throes of a friendship mirroring the seedy demise of the hippie period, delivering some comic gems along the way.
A spotty, uneven satire (from the novel by Terry Southern) with a number of good yocks, but insufficient sustained wit or related action.
Chong lights up the film like a firefly, Schwarzenegger delivers a certain light touch of his own, [and] the result is palatable action comics.
The artful cinematic strokes of director Robert Wise and staff are not quite enough to override the major shortcomings of Nelson Gidding's screenplay.
Given the talents, Poltergeist is an annoying film because it could have been so much better.
A mish-mash of violence, psycho-drama and lukewarm kiddie comedy.

Story is confused and confusing, and while with the aid of heavily-shadowed lighting and mausoleum-like architecture, a certain eeriness has been achieved, it's all a poor imitation of things seen before.
It has some queasy scenes, but unclear progression and plodding direction give this an old-fashioned air.
Kinski was essential to the film as conceived, and she's endlessly watchable.
High-powered but pared down, slick but spare, this is a tale that introduces the unearthly into the banality of rural American existence.
Despite some major structural weaknesses, the cannily manipulated combination of mystery, gore and kinky sex adds up to a slick commercial package.
Chris Sarandon is terrific as the vampire, quite affable and debonair until his fingernails start to grow and his eyes get that glow.
Less than successful, veering from poignant emotionalism to broad slapstick in sudden shifts.
Martin's trademark wacky humor is fitfully in evidence, but seems much more repressed than usual in order to fit into the relatively realistic world of single working people.
The mind boggles to learn that Lynch labored on this pic for five years.

Murder by Death is a very good silly-funny Neil Simon satirical comedy, with a super all-star cast cavorting as recognizable pulp fiction detectives gathered at the home of Truman Capote, wealthy hedonist fed up with contrived gumshoe plots.
One of Woody Allen's great films. Indeed, he makes nary a misstep from beginning to end in charting the amorous affiliations of three sisters and their men over a two-year period.
This masterwork operates in the intimate, thoughtful vein of the great BBC bios of artistic figures.
A harrowing, gruesome, morbid tale of war.
movie_title: All Quiet on the Western Front (1930)

movie_review_blurb: Hudson is handsome and somewhat wooden. Laconic of speech, and imbued with an angel's patience and understanding, it's at times hard to understand his passion for the widow, what with pretty girls just spoilingfor his attention.
Uniformly good performances and some equally good direction and dialog keep the meller moving.
It's a corking program picture, thanks to George Bancroft, a good story and Julian Johnson's titles.

A corking story, exceptionally acted and cleverly directed. A lot of glory to be distributed among all concerned.
The film version of Gore Vidal's Hollywood-themed transsexual satire starts off promisingly, but after a couple of reels plunges straight downhill under the weight of artless direction.

The murky lighting, uninteresting human characters and violence of the original have been modified in the more amiable sequel, mostly to good effect.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II - The Secret of the Ooze (1991)

movie_review_blurb: Bergman has come up with probably one of his most masterful films technically and in conception, but also one of his most difficult ones.

Offers a few good scares but gets bogged down in special effects.

An extremely literate science-fiction drama.

This British-Italian suspenser, in which the horror gets to one almost subliminally, as in Rosemary's Baby, is superior stuff.

Occasionally a feature film emerges from the midwest, although this is the first ever out of Lawrence, Kans, where a group of commercial film pros veered off into a try at producing theatrical entertainment.

A highly imaginative horror film that provides the requisite shocks to keep fans of the genre happy.

Well mounted, nicely directed, and includes cast of capable artists.

Overcrowded with trite dialog and ponderous acting.
The chain of circumstances grows, violence creating violence. Once the inept, draggy start is passed, the film's pace builds with ever-growing force.

movie_review_blurb: An expert telling of a supernatural horror story.

Only intermittently impressive.

A fantastically subversive film, a nifty little confection pitting us vs them, the haves vs the have-nots.

Rousing, good story, told with vigor and visual excitement by Akira Kurosawa, and splendidly acted by Toshiro Mifune, this has ideal remake material for a Yank company.

For sheer crowd-pleasing fun it belts one high into the left-field bleachers.
For baseball and non-baseball fan alike, this sentimental, romantic saga of the NY kid who rose to the baseball heights and later met such a tragic end is well worth seeing.

An unusually downbeat and depressing youth pic.
Pretty in Pink is a rather intelligent (if not terribly original) look at adolescent insecurities.

An impressively sharp directorial debut highlighted by some good bedroom farce.

movie_title: Don't Tell Mom the Babysitter's Dead (1991)

movie_review_blurb: A fanciful, unconvincing 'love conquers all' scenario emerges.
There's enough bite and bawdiness to provide lots of smiles and several broad guffaws.

The entire charade is smoothly contrived.
Notre Dame professor Edward Fischer has said that 'the best films, like the best books, tell how it is to be human under certain circumstances'. Larry McMurtry did a beautiful job of this.

Walt Disney's production of 20000 Leagues under the Sea is very special kind of picture, combining photographic ingenuity, imaginative story telling and fiscal daring.
Gibson impressively fleshes out Max, Tina Turner is striking in her role as Aunty (as well as contributing two topnotch songs, which open and close the picture) and the juves are uniformly good.

If it's the most vividly guesome monster ever to stalk the screen that audiences crave, then The Thing is the thing. On all other levels, however, John Carpenter's remake of Howard Hawks' 1951 sci-fi classic comes as a letdown.
Director Roger Corman keeps this moving and Ray Milland is competent as the doomed man. Special effects on his prism-eye world, called Spectarama, are good if sometimes repetitive.
Film is dotted with video jargon and ideology which proves more fascinating than distancing. And Cronenberg amplifies the freaky situation with a series of stunning visual effects.
Establishes [its] British director as one of the most talented and imaginative new filmmakers in this part of the world. It's a demanding effort which will provide a challenge.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

Lacks authenticity and is so far fetched it'll hand newsscribes around the country a constant run of ripples. But it's light and has some funny lines and situations.

Astoundingly tedious.

A fancy package of musical entertainment with wide appeal and bright grossing prospects.
In the end M.A.S.H. succeeds, in spite of its glaring faults.

Suffers from a terminal case of creative indecision.
A nostalgic throwback to the genteel British murder mystery pix of the 1950s.
Basically consists of a wide assortment of character riffs which are offbeat enough to provide moderate moment-to-moment amusement but don't create a great deal of comic impact.
Pomeranc is wonderfully real and wide-eyed as Josh, with a raspy voice and slight lisp recalling Linus from the Peanuts cartoons.
An absorbing narrative flow and a parade of colorful underworld characters vie for screen time with an unsatisfactory central romance.
[Where the Buffalo Roam] features a number of amusing set-pieces of irreverent lunacy, but lack of serious substance renders film too frivolous and detached from reality.
A well intentioned fantasy with some wonderful special effects, Dragonslayer falls somewhat short on continuously intriguing adventure.
Given the powerhouse topline casting combo and provocative theme, True Confessions has to be chalked up as something of a disappointment.
Bad Company is an excellent film which combines wry humor and gritty action with in-depth characterizations of two youths on the lam in the Civil War west.
The story is excellently conceived and planned.
No Way Out is an effective updating and revamping of the 1948 film noir classic The Big Clock.
The tender story, with its frank and unashamed assault on the emotions, still has its effective moments at times when the sentiment doesn't grow a little too thick.
If The Four Seasons was never a play, it should have been, since it's based on the most stagey, dialog-bound original screenplay in memory.
It is difficult to single out performances in the uniformly excellent casts, which feature some of the top talent in Poland.
Billy Dee Williams and James Earl Jones are superb.
movie_title: The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars & Motor Kings (1976)

movie_review_blurb: While not fully successful, either as drama or ideology, film is marked by superb camera and montage technique recalling some of the firstrate German productions before the Nazi era.
movie_title: Murderers Are Among Us (Die Mörder sind unter uns) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: La Bamba is engrossing throughout and boasts numerous fine performances.
Though it looks ravishing, Warren Beatty's longtime pet project is a curiously remote, uninvolving film.
Fault is in the writing and direction, both staying on the surface and never getting underneath the characters.
Interesting movement holds through the entirety. Life in the native quarter, with its squalor and intrigues, is particularly well presented and photographed.
Cagney has an excellent supporting cast.

Perry Henzell emerges a director with a solid visual flair who can mix action and inchoate rage sans excess to give the film a taut pacing and use the local color and a basically predictable tale with a few new twists.

Laboring under the handicaps of a contrived script, an uncertain approach and personalities in essence playing themselves, the production never quite makes its point, but romps along merrily unconcerned that it doesn't.
John Waters' mischievous satire of the teen exploitation genre is entertaining as a rude joyride through another era, full of great clothes and hairdos.
Despite Haxell Wexler's alluring lensing, this thinly dramatized, overly episodic Babe Ruth biopic resembles a telepic that has lost its way onto the big screen.
Delphine Seyrig's silver lame presence and Harry Kumel's evocative direction make this an above-par vampire tale.
Norman Jewison usually is a commanding storyteller, but In Country is a film with two stories that fail to add up to something greater.
Ferdy Mayne is the menacing Dracula, and Sharon Tate, lady in question, looks particularly nice in her bath.
Morrisey long showed that his films, although more implicit in sex, drugs and characterizations, were really Hollywood films at the core.
Poor Bo no sooner has her initial introduction to amour than the new lover gets gored in a sensitive location, putting him out of commission.
Dunne gives an excellent performance, as does Alan Marshal, playing her husband, while Roddy McDowall stands out sharply as their son.

Mills amusingly hams his way through two or three sequences as one of the dying brothers. Richardson, bland, imperturable old bore, is superb. He and Wilfrid Lawson, portraying a decrepit butler, virtually carry away the acting honors.
Robert Englund, receiving star billing for the first time, is delightful in his frequent incarnations as Freddy, delivering his gag lines with relish and making the grisly proceedings funny.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master (1988)

movie_review_blurb: The seemingly can't-miss premise of teen-heartthrob gangsters gets lost in self-important direction, a shoddy script and muddled storytelling.
Chief fault is that the picture over-emphasizes the single hanging incident of the novel, and there's not enough other action.
Fast and vigorous in walloping over the comedy.
The laughs roll along readily as Wilder tries one idea after another to sneak out on wife Judith Ivey and family to rendevous with Le Brock.
This is a boy's movie all the way.
The playing is exceptional, both men and women.
Like a standup comic pouring 'flopsweat', this ill-conceived comedy about an infant whose thoughts are given voice by actor Bruce Willis palpitates with desperation.
Ultimately it is in the design and engineering of cumulative sight gag situations that Thrill of It All excels.
A powerful metaphor of the national shame that was America's orgy of destruction in Vietnam, Brian De Palma's film deals directly with the harrowing rape and murder of a Vietnamese woman by four GIs.
Underneath it all is a lurching and poorly defined film concept.
Zina Bethune, as the girl, is believable but Harvey Keitel, as the anti-hero, is alternatively boorish or bewildered.
movie_title: Who's That Knocking at My Door? (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Concise progression, fine technical aspects, and the look at innocence destroyed by the profane keeps it absorbing, despite the slightly pretentious treatment at times.
This is a weird drama of thrill-chill caliber.
Plenty of direction and as much photography. There doesn't appear to be a miss or skip either.
D.W. Griffith is down to common picture making in this one.
Pic is guilty of the sins it condemns - superficiality, manipulation and smugness.

The Sunshine Boys is an extremely sensitive and lovable film version of Neil Simon's play, with Walter Matthau and George Burns outstanding in their starring roles as a pair of long-hostile vaudeville partners.
The three stories just don't connect and efforts to join them never work. However, an excellent roster of talent does try its best.
Lucille Fletcher's Night Watch isn't the first average stage play to be turned into a better than average film. Astute direction and an improved cast more than help.
House by the River is a fair mystery which lacks sufficient plot twists and suspense.
Heaven Can Wait is an outstanding film.
Mel Brooks will do anything for a laugh. Unfortunately, what he does in Spaceballs, a misguided parody of the Star Wars adventures, isn't very funny.

Pic isn't acted but 'lived.' Pro and non-pro cast play it with uniform sincerity. Edmund Meschke is the most impressive of the lot, delivering a poignant, believable portrayal as the young disgraced hero.
The Hall Caine novel from which this film was adapted is a weak one, but the director has done his best with it.
Newcomer Witherspoon manages to strike exactly the right note as the tomboy on the verge of womanhood while Waterston works on several levels at once.
Drawn from real life, the conflict between cultures is good for both a laugh and a sober thought along the way.
Red Sonja returns to those olden days when women were women and the menfolk stood around with funny hats on until called forth to be whacked at.
Veidt has a strong role for which he's admirably suited. Sebastian Shaw is excellent as the English naval officer. Valerie Hobson, as the other spy, is creditable.

Edward G. Robinson means a lot to this entertainment.
Skolimowski has been able to create a gripping film that holds attention most of the way through its economical length.
Pic takes to the 70mm process with an extraordinary impressionistic outdoor set of a new Paris, and is an observant romp during a one-day stay of a group of tourists.
The picture has a strange sort of power that overcomes the total lack of logic.

Whatever elements of suspense, action and motivation the Louis Bromfield book, McLeod's Folly, may have held to attract the Cagney production staff, the screen treatment which has emerged is, for the most part, familiar melodrama.
Slick, sure-footed entertainment, one part buddy comedy and one part police actioner stitched together with a dash of romance.

This multiple-murder story is an offbeat sort of film, with Robert Wagner portraying a calculating youth who intends to allow nothing to stand in his way to money... Gerd Oswald's restrained direction suits the mood.

In spite of the painstaking attempts to explore the characters of the picture's three principal heroes (Bowie, Crockett, Travis), there is an absence of emotional feeling, of a sense of participation.
Schrader's third outing as a director is betrayed by a curious, uncharacteristic evasiveness at its core.
As a film it's slow. Very. The first hour is wandering, planting-the-plot stuff that has some difficulty cementing the interest, but in the final stretch it grips and holds.
Gerald Thomas' direction as usual is assured, though some of the gags and situations would be helped by speeding up via more ruthless trimming.
Beyond the Poseidon Adventure comes off as a virtual remake of the 1972 original, without that film's mounting suspense and excitement.

It's a personal and profound work.

Opulence of Imperial Russia at the beginning of the 19th century provides a colorful background for this filmization of Alexander Pushkin's short story, which brings to the screen a legend of gambling and intrigue.

Idiotic premise has US government genetic engineering experiments creating a deadly form of grunions (hinted at being used in the Vietnam war).
Cooper's playing could not be improved upon.

The earlier films in the series were far from perfect, but at their best they had some flair and agreeable humor, qualities this one sorely lacks.
movie_title: Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987)

movie_review_blurb: A half-baked retread of tired MTV imagery and childish themes.

movie_title: The Good Mother (The Price of Passion) (1988)

A modestly executed, off-target police drama giving actor James Woods another outlet for his compellingly schizophrenic persona.
A thoroughly offbeat but most enjoyable comedy on the subject of food.

Elliott Nugent's direction skips along the surface of the era depicted. The script doesn't give him much substance to work with.

A disappointer. Much of the blame is to be laid at director Josef von Sternberg's doorstep.

movie_review_blurb: Watch on the Rhine is a distinguished picture. It is even better than its powerful original stage version.
Not as classy a farce as the original, but still manages to be an amusing romp for most of its length.
This is good entertainment.

movie_review_blurb: Damon Wayans and his younger brother Marlon make a terrific comedy team in Mo' Money.

Berri is unable to overcome the inherent feebleness of the Manon character, here played ineffectually by the lovely and talented Emmanuelle Beart.
movie_title: Manon of the Spring (Manon des Sources) (1987)

movie_review_blurb: Music is the usual medley of pop dance stuff, with the cabaret set about the best thing in the production. Camerawork on close-ups is excellent.

Genuine and moving.
Jean Cocteau's scripting and directing give the film its proper key of unworldliness.

ith Vittorio De Sica's direction, the eye-pleasing atmosphere of the Italian Alps and Marcello Mastroianni and Faye Dunaway a good team as a pair of ill-starred lovers, there's enough pull.

Though it is less tasteless, irreverent and satirical than the Python pics, film still is wacky and occasionally outrageous in its own, distinctly British way.

St. Elmo's Fire is all about a group of recent college graduates in Washington who were always the best of friends but now are drifting apart as real life approaches, discovering various reasons why they are so individually obnoxious.

A thoughtful, endearing film charting the life of singer Loretta Lynn from the depths of poverty in rural Kentucky to her eventual rise to the title of 'queen of country music'.

A fitting final installment in Terry Gilliam's trilogy begun with Time Bandits and continued with Brazil.
The madcap Marxes, in one of their maddest screen frolics.
A thriller without much surprise, suspense or excitement.
This is a sexy, nuanced, beautifully controlled examination of how a quartet of people are defined by their erotic impulses and inhibitions.

Tandy is at her sparkling best as the endearing old story-teller. Bates is also terrif in a funny and sympathetic turn. Director Jon Avnet, in his feature film debut, gets first-rate work from the featured performers.

A too-broad comedy, mostly due to the poor performance of Michael Caine.

[An] earnest, often moving but not totally successful film.

movie_review_blurb: William Powell and Carole Lombard are pleasantly teamed in this splendidly produced comedy.

An incomprehensible melange of striking imagery, obscure dialog, a powerful score, and a script that doesn't know how to go from A to B.

No harmful false note is struck.

Faithful in substantial degree not only to the letter but also the spirit of the 1933 classic for RKO, this $22 million-plus version neatly balances superb special effects with solid dramatic credibility.

An outstanding film.

Scarface contains more cruelty than any of its gangster picture predecessors, but there's a squarer for every killing. The blows are always softened by judicial preachments and sad endings for the sinners.

This Fellini opus is his most accessible to mass audiences since La Dolce Vita.

Intended by director Julian Temple and his screenwriters to affectionately skewer Tinseltown lifestyles.

In the end it's hopelessly sappy stuff.

An artless, non-stop barrage of off-the-wall situations, funny and unfunny jokes, generally effective and sometimes hilarious sight gags and bawdy non sequiturs.

A hodge-podge of bits and pieces.
Nelson Gidding's adaptation of the Michael Crichton novel is too literal and talky.
A silly and unconvincing contempo sci-fi thriller.
So choppily assembled none of the various clues and innumerable suspects ever seem to lead anywhere.

A western meller done in the best John Ford manner.
The film is too schematic by half and overflows with one-dimensional characters.

A thoroughly entertaining screen adaptation of novelist E.M. Forster's comedy of manners about the Edwardian English upper class at home and abroad, distinguished by superb ensemble acting, intelligent writing and stunning design.

A pleasant film about an old man who rejuvenates himself on a cross-country trek.

All performances are on the mark in this perfect little film.

the camp aspects simply give way to the ridiculous while failing to establish any rules to govern the mayhem. The result is plenty of unintentional laughs.

The movie, with room to gallop through nearly two hours and an R rating, often just kicks around in the stable.
movie_title: Cowboy Bebop: The Movie (Kaubôi Bibappu: Tengoku no Tobira) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Jordan's approach assumes a certain intelligence, and attentiveness, in his audience, but his joyride through the French Riviera always keeps us belted in.
Collapses into a public service announcement on gambling.
Fails to engage us in the lives of its characters because it never really introduces them.
Never shies from indulging us and our desire for a gentle and generous world that doesn't slip into easy answers.
The Skeleton Key opens a very different door into its tale of black magic in a Louisiana plantation home.

Schneider, who co-wrote the script, has succeeded in making a film that's nearly review-proof: Most of the dialogue -- packed with names for fictitious sex acts and the gigolos who perfect them -- is unrepeatable in a newspaper.
More a collage than a movie.
Endearing little film.
Slow and satisfying.
The movie can feel slow and tedious, but the supper it makes us work for is nourishing.

Bubba Ho-Tep succeeds as goofy-yet- tender wish fulfillment, offering an Elvis who tries to redeem his self-indulgent persona and become a hero. It fails as the sort of Campbell vehicle that wears out VCRs and haunts midnight-movie houses.
Exhibits a devotion to its subject that just might drive you to his books and make you wish for tea with the man who wrote them.
After sampling the crostini and extended-family love baked by the Brothers Pyzola, you might make the Biscotti Co. a second home.
Gorlin lacks a coherent recipe for his savory ingredients.
Few movies create such perfect pitch among character, plot and setting.
The journey's the thing, and nearly every kilometer of it holds adventure, charm and laughter.

This film stands out for its visuals that takes the viewer under the ground to relive the suffocation and pain that thousands of Mexicans suffered in 1985's earthquake, a wound that will never heal. [Full review in Spanish]
A very posh film that repeats what the director had done previously. [Full review in Spanish]
Pink contributes to a distorted reality about what being gay is. [Full review in Spanish]
A powerful drama about one of the mos controversial subjects in recent memory: pederasty in the Catholic Church. [Full review in Spanish]
Avengers: Age of Ultron is the sequel of a profitable Marvel franchise, but it's far less interesting and powerful than the first instalment.
7 Days in Hell is flush with over-the-top raunch and absurdist asides, but there's a shaggy charm about this production, a sort of "let's put on a show!" quality that is easy to warm to.
Queen Latifah delivers a rich, full-throated performance as the Empress of the Blues.
Even if you are familiar with the contours of the controversy over Scientology, Gibney's documentary... is worth watching, particularly for the personal stories of former members.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Grease Live! raised the bar for choreography - which, given Hough's experience, shouldn't be surprising.
Smarts, heart and nerve: The Wiz Live! had it all.
Neither a stimulating satire nor a serious exposure of the operations of the finance industry.
The press release makes a "special request" to not reveal the ending. They didn't need to worry. Anyone over PG-13 age is going to know exactly where this movie is going long before it gets there.
The problem with the film is that others have done its routine before, and have done it better.
Overall, there's just not enough story here.
As satanic flicks go, Bless the Child is entertaining, but it doesn't add enough to the genre to make it truly blessed.
The film uses every standard urban drama story line in the book.
This rich piece of civil war history has become oddly desiccated.
After what can only be described as an audaciously bleak opening act, Sunset Song makes a gentle, sweeping turn towards greener pastures on behalf of its redoubtable heroine.
Captain Fantastic's alternative lifestyle model might ultimately prove to be flawed, but the film still offers a convincing and frequently hilarious critique of conventional social mores.
Real belly laughs are few and far between.

Tom Hanks is as solid as ever in the role of Sullenberger, a stoic who is trying to hold it together under immense pressure -- from without and within. But... the character, while earning our respect, is a little hard to warm to.

What it lacks in ground-breaking developments, it makes up for with the tenacious charm of its lead terrier Max (Louis C.K.) and the surprising sass of his most ardent admirer, a white Pomeranian named Gidget (Jenny Slate).
The two directors entitled their film Nerve. It's a pity they didn't hold theirs.
Ron Howard's feature-length documentary, the first to be authorised by the band since its breakup in 1970, offers audiences a well-paced and thoroughly engaging recap.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Watching Renée Zellweger reanimate the character of Bridget Jones 12-years on is a lot like reconnecting with an old friend.
A magical tale of love and letting go.
Clive Owen wears a checked flannie better than your average movie star.
Not so much a remake or a reboot as a fairly uninspired remix.
Edward Snowden doesn't fit the stereotypical image of a political activist or rabble rouser. And that's what gives Oliver Stone's forensically-minded docudrama its narrative traction.
Jack Huston's Judah also feels strangely diminished when judged alongside Charlton Heston's chiselled machismo in the same role.
If David Lynch imagined an encounter between Red Riding Hood and Mean Girls' plastics on the way to Napoleon Dynamite's house, it might turn out something like Girl Asleep.
As an ensemble, the actors underplay their roles to perfection.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Greengrass and Damon certainly can't be accused of cynical opportunism in returning to the franchise -- they've made a solid attempt, here, to honour both the character and his legions of fans.
A good film that could have been a great one.
With this keenly observed comedy of manners, director Whit Stillman has successfully reimagined the period romance for contemporary audiences. Sharp, funny and briskly paced.
Gyllenhaal is terrific as Davis, a role that requires him to control his emotions until they threaten to pop, and then incrementally, imperceptibly let the pressure off.
The spectres are scarier than in the original film. And the action is slicker. But the humour is surprisingly patchy in Paul Feig's hotly-anticipated Ghostbusters reboot.
A large part of the film's success rests on the shoulders of its actors, who rarely overplay their hand.
movie_title: As It Is In Heaven 2: Heaven On Earth (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pedro Almodovar seduces his audience from the opening credits of this fertile Spanish melodrama about love, loss and reinvention.
As a piece of storytelling, Embrace is similarly intimate and idiosyncratic. And that's what makes it so accessible.
As a piece of storytelling, Absolutely Fabulous is fairly patchy. But the movie's larger-than-life format provides Edina and Patsy with a welcome opportunity to plumb new comedic depths.
While the violent B-Movie is far from autobiographical, it does offer the fallen screen idol a chance to acknowledge his past crimes and misdemeanours in a manner that plays to his strengths.
Down Under is too ugly to be funny.
Tissues are probably not required -- director Cesc Gay isn't inclined to let his audiences off the hook so lightly.
Softly-spoken but emotionally potent.
Sweet, engaging, accessible family entertainment.
Miscreant matriarchs? Oh, puh-lease!
Groceries aren't an obvious fit for the bawdy comedy of Rogen and his Superbad, Pineapple Express screenwriting partner-in-crime Evan Goldberg. That's a large part of Sausage Party's appeal.
On its own brutally efficient B-movie terms, The Shallows works exceptionally well.
The deeper they dig, the stranger the story gets.
As always, The Joker stands apart. And that's what makes him so fascinating.
A convincing and terrifying dramatisation of events in the Gulf of Mexico on April 20, 2010, from the point of view of the men and women who experienced it.
Most of the time, the characters feels as though they are one beat away from something awful happening. And this tension keeps us involved even when the pacing falters.
In the end, the success of Joe Cinque's Consolation rests almost entirely on the shoulders of its lead actress, Wentworth's Maggie Naouri.
As a piece of animation, Trolls is beautifully textured.
As the titular Founder, Keaton embodies the American dream in all its strengths, shortcomings and contradictions.
Dancer is worth watching just to see the prodigious talent in full flight.
There's something half-formed about the Blood Wars narrative. This is reflected in the CGI, elements of which are surprisingly crude.
A beautifully-observed account of friendship and human frailty.
Queen of Katwe walks the line between integrity and accessibility with grace and dignity.
Moana (Auli'i Cravalho) could be the most fully developed royal Disney heroine yet.
True Blue has the same knockabout charm as its record-breaking predecessor.
Jyn represents a new breed of (almost gender-neutral) hero: dogged, tenacious, resolute. And in a world as bleak as this one, that's what amounts to hope.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Underneath its impeccably-tailored glad rags, however, Allied is about as animated as one of Madame Tussaud's waxwork dummies.
Directed by Amma Asante (who helmed Belle with a similarly sure and light touch) A United Kingdom is a powerful story told with grace, dignity and restraint.

While there is much to recommend Damien Chazelle's ode to Hollywood musicals of the 40s and 50s, there were times when I found myself curiously out of step with the rambling, retro production and the self-involved nature of the world in which it is set.
The last 30 minutes warms the heart as well as bringing the house down.
The film's leisurely pacing, which might take a moment to adjust to, mirrors the bus driver's own unhurried rhythm, allowing the audience to experience the world from his very particular perspective.
Writer-director John Carney successfully rehabilitates the movie musical in this heartwarming coming-of-age story set in Dublin in the 1980s.
Even by the relatively low standards set by Christmas comedies, Bad Santa 2 is a fail.
In the end, The Girl on the Train runs out of track.
Few odd couples are fleshed out with as much care and attention.
I, Daniel Blake is an important story, powerfully told. But Loach's message would have been even more affecting had he delivered it in a slightly less didactic manner.
The atmosphere is evocative and the pacing tense, but Verso's ambitious screenplay would benefit from some judicious editing.
The result is a solid, but rather unimaginative thriller that keeps us guessing until the credits roll but leaves us with nothing much left to ruminate over on the drive/train ride home.
It's Stewart, however, who grounds this film with the sort of strong, naturalistic performance that is fast becoming her trademark.
Gibson is in his element here. When the barrage hits, it has a force that leaves even the audience winded.
Galifianakis's bad hair is the first obvious clue of the filmmakers' creative miscalculation.

There hasn't been a spy couple this perfect since, well, Mr and Mrs Smith. Don Draper and Wonder Woman are well cast as the Joneses, two ultra-sophisticated, impossibly gorgeous, happily-married undercover operatives.
Elle is not a particularly deep exploration of rape and its surrounding trauma, power relationships and fantasies. But it does raise some intriguing questions.
Never Go Back is neither original or subtle, but like its titular enforcer, it gets the job done.
Mackenzie gives every one of his actors the opportunity to show what stuff they are made of. And they deliver, each in their own way.
As an action thriller, the Accountant does little more than balance its books.
Once Doctor Strange is paired with his scene-stealing magic cape, Cumberbatch's character literally and figuratively takes flight.
Nocturnal Animals is a colder, more misanthropic creation. But the resolution of the intertwining narratives is expertly-handled. And the film's impact lingers long after the credits have rolled.
Arrival is reaching for something it can't quite grab hold of. But it comes a whole lot closer than most.

The story might be familiar but the setting is very specific. The production design and lighting palette is similarly distinctive. Performances are universally strong and the romance between Nelis and a fellow teacher is nicely underplayed.
A strangely hypnotic experience.

The Irishman has a wicked way with words and a wideranging sense of humour -- in War on Everyone, there are jokes-within-jokes-within jokes. But McDonagh's first film to be set in America lacks the humanity of his earlier works.

Our Kind Of Traitor isn't in the same duplicitous league as the best Le Carre adaptations... But director Susanna White holds her nerve with this intelligent, character-driven entry into the espionage universe.
Shine a Light reinvigorates a slightly tired genre with an extraordinarily light touch.
A good deal of the pleasure to be derived from The Wait comes from watching two strong actresses at different stages of their careers bounce off the other.
A singularly unsuccessful look at mature love.
A solid sequel for the reinvented franchise.
This is good, clean G-rated escapism delivered by fresh, talented young performers.
Boyle confidently mines the feelgood opportunities of Simon Beaufoy's screenplay, adapted from Vikas Swarup's novel, without letting the film collapse into soppiness or sentimentality.
Although the story wobbles at times, Seven Pounds stays the course thanks to Muccino's skilled direction.
Rourke's Golden Globe award is as richly deserved as it was popular. Like the sport it celebrates, his performance doesn't hold anything back.
As close to a blood sport as is humanly possibly for something that doesn't involve any physical contact.
Gran Torino is to Dirty Harry what Unforgiven was to The Outlaw Josey Wales.
A cold and unappealing drama that is almost cripplingly middle-class.
A well-paced thriller that sheds light on a little-known piece of World War II history.
Milk is the full-cream deal; an artery-testing tale of love, politics, human rights and heartbreak.
A deftly handled tale about one woman's quiet and determined struggle to overcome seemingly insurmountable odds.
Part satire, part biopic, part behind-the scenes political drama, W gets stranded in a no-man's land somewhere in between.

A fast-paced and serviceable thriller, dressed in second-hand religious mumbo jumbo, that relies on constant forward momentum to ensure its audience doesn't have time to stop and think about it too much.
Dawn of the Dinosaurs so successfully reinvigorates an already solid franchise, while simultaneously broadening the fan base, that you can already see the fourth film gathering on the horizon.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A taut and topical thriller that attempts to add a human dimension to the fast-paced and often explosive action.
Harry Potter trades hocus pocus for real dramatic magic in Half-Blood Prince.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Promoted as a story of 'sex, thugs and rock'n'roll,' this highly stylised mobster movie couldn't even be remotely confused with the real thing.
While Pegg has a good stab at lending the film some of his trademark knockabout charm, the film is as artless and difficult to warm to as its leading man.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Orphanage takes audiences on an eerie, involving and ultimately extremely moving journey into the underworld.
When it comes to exploring the big picture, space provides filmmakers with pretty much a blank canvas.
This is the slightest of Clooney's directorial offerings, but it's carried over the line by two charismatic leads and a well-honed screenplay.
The appeal of this frenetically-paced fantasy is probably limited to 10-year-olds, gamers and fanboys.
A solid superhero fantasy that gains added depth from a strong cast.
The possibility of a fourth film is alluded to in the screenplay, but let's hope the filmmakers decide to leave that one where it belongs -- in the crypt.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: We're left with the nasty taste of our own bloodlust long after the credits have rolled.
A visual tonic of a film, wise enough to give its audience plenty of space.
Despite valiant efforts from a seasoned cast, it fails to deliver the expected laughs.
Fraser salvages his reputation as a solid, matinee-style action hero in this family-oriented fantasy.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film unfolds at such breakneck speed that the credits are rolling before it becomes fully apparent that the storyline actually ran out of gas some way back.
A handsome costume drama that highlights the relationship between the Cinderella outfits and the restrictive privilege of the society from whence they came.
Since they have so little material to work with in the first place, Friedberg and Seltzer flog each joke well beyond its limits.
As uncomfortable to watch as it is compelling, this film adaptation of Alicia Erian's novel is saved from mere ordeal status by a hopeful and uncliched ending.
A timely update on a deserving classic.
Even a dream cast has to have the right material to work with. As well as a filmmaker who can bring out the best in them.
The film feels slighter than its hugely successful predecessor.
A morally ambiguous tearjerker with a twist.
Public Enemies finds [Mann] a bit slower on his feet. The film lacks the narrative dexterity of Collateral and The Insider. And the end result veers between solid and stolid.
In his fourth stint in the director's chair, Bryan Singer does a masterful job weaving new material with past storylines and great imagery.
This film is a rough-cut, homegrown gem.
A smart, entertaining, well-paced thriller.
The first film borrowed so heavily from both books there is very little left for screenwriter Linda Wolverton to work with. And it shows.
Compared to Captain America: Civil War and even X-Men: Apocaylpse, Out of the Shadows feels like it's playing in the little league.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film's most impressive trick might be director Jon M Chu's ability to distract his audience from the realisation that this illusionist spin on the con caper is getting dangerously low on gas.
For moviegoers looking to lose themselves in an old-school epic, Queen Of The Desert certainly fits the bill. But as a celebration of the life of a feminist pioneer, the film is sorely lacking.
Horror-meister James Wan had yours truly pretty much from the opening sequence. And he didn't let go until the final credits rolled.
The 5.5 million active subscribers to the gaming phenomenon deserve better.

Finding Dory has some great new characters -- Ed O'Neill's cantankerous Octopus, Ty Burrell's beluga whale and Kaitlin Olson's whale shark stand out. The animation is exquisite. A good portion of the film, however, feels reheated.
Cheadle hits the odd bum note, but his affection for his subject is never in doubt. And he gets right under the musician's skin.

Erguven's assured direction seals the deal. There's a mythical quality to this tale of burgeoning female sexuality that transcends the more hackneyed elements of the plot and marks her out as a director to watch.
Special mention should go to the Everybody Want Some!! hair and make-up department -- the lead actors' retro look is so convincing, you'd swear you were watching a documentary.
Even with his superior instincts, the mythical hero can't find a way through the confused screenplay.
Funny, sharply observed -- and occasionally profound.
Bastille Day might be a step up from Gerard Butler's jingoistic London Has Fallen, but that's hardly a recommendation.
The Meddler is Sarandon's film. The genuine pluckiness Marnie exhibits in the face of aching sadness makes her a winning character. It's the actress's juiciest role in years.
The jaunty story has enough kinetic energy to keep young audiences engaged. And it remains truthful to the anarchic spirit of the game on which it is based.
Creed is a franchise-reinvigorating reboot that can hold its own alongside a very select few.
Part outback mystery, part kitchen-sink drama, Beautiful Kate is a remarkably assured directorial debut from Ward, who has honed her craft on short films.
The world Blomkamp has created in this original creature feature is at once familiar and distinctive.
It's a good deal more interesting than your average mainstream comedy.
For a film that lost one of its key players, Heath Ledger, mid-way through production, The Imaginarium Of Doctor Parnassus is remarkably cohesive. Marks a return to form for Gilliam.

Like Donnie Darko, The Box's eerily effective atmosphere of paranoid conspiracy would not hold up to too much scrutiny. Fans of that twisted sci-fi conundrum will need no further encouragement to see this follow-up in the same vein.
Sure to hit the spot for anyone with an appetite for sweet, unselfconscious romantic fantasy.
In terms of providing plenty of bang for one's buck, Breaking Dawn Part 2 definitely ends the franchise on a high note.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Noir fades to rouge in the harsh glare of the Aussie Outback. And few filmmakers are better qualified than Ivan Sen to capture this fascinating tonal shift.

When the first Star Wars film was released in 1977, nobody had seen anything like it. Almost 40 years on, the trail it blazed is now so well traveled, it's on every intergalactic tourist map.That makes Abrams' feat all the more impressive.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Foster holds nothing back in his extremely committed portrayal of one thoroughly nasty piece of work. But it's hard to go the distance with such a mean-minded protagonist.
Genuinely appealing.
The most interesting interpretation of Romeo and Juliet since Baz Luhrmann's groundbreaking 1996 version.

Breezily paced, deftly plotted, confidently played -- this wildly entertaining dramedy about a desk-bound TV news reporter who impulsively accepts a job in war-torn Afghanistan has plenty to recommend it. Top of that list is Tina Fey,
Although Youth is more uneven than its predecessor, a string of powerful images​ linger long after the credits have rolled.
An extraordinary achievement.

From this beginning, Sorkin and Boyle add layer upon layer of shadowing to their portrait of Jobs as ruthless, driven, obsessive, and extraordinarily charismatic, aided in no small part by Michael Fassbender's brilliant performance.
It takes an actress of the calibre of Jennifer Lawrence to successfully convey The Hunger Games protagonist's existential conundrum.
The elliptical narrative structure keeps audiences guessing for much longer than one might expect.
Tamahori's meticulous attention to historical detail transports us back to a very specific time and place.
Raw, painful and excruciatingly funny, Toni Erdmann might just be one of a kind.
A disappointingly mannered and over-thunk film interpretation of Koch's bare-knuckled literary thriller.
It has all the essential ingredients for a superior psychological thriller. Muschietti is the masterchef who knows just how to combine them.
Dench's imperious performance keeps the film afloat, but as a piece of storytelling, Victoria and Abdul is disturbingly glib.
Director Raoul Peck picks up where the author left off, using the unfinished manuscript as a kind of blueprint for this incendiary, Oscar-nominated documentary.
Whether you like the film or loathe it, you can be damn sure you won't have seen anything like it.
Initially, the story is carried along by the momentum of its characters. But when they run out of steam, so does the screenplay.
Battle Of the Sexes is a well-played crowd pleaser with a decent backhand volley.
A disappointingly plastic addition to both the Lego and ninja cannons.
Like its predecessor, the new version also nails the horror elements.

Stanley Tucci knows just how to direct his Oscar-winning lead in Final Portrait - containing that theatrical flourish within a relatively economical storyline. It makes for a film in which watching paint dry is oddly fascinating.
At the heart of this off-balance heist movie is a story of brotherly love.
In a multiplex environment in which even comic book superheroes are psychologically complex, American Assassin misses its target by a surprisingly large margin.
Seldom has the link between Uranus jokes and the survival of mankind been drawn so convincingly.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Dancer's screenplay - based on the novel by Giovanni Lista - is positively clumsy.
Witherspoon, so good in her passion project Wild, mugs it mercilessly for the camera. It's as if she, too, is wrong-footed by the lack of canned laughter.
Girls Trip's overriding focus is that of friendship -- in its all its raw, bawdy, compromised glory.
An odd and oddly affecting rite of passage.
Gifted's two leads make great travelling companions.
Not even the growling intensity of Elba's righteous cowboy is enough to carry The Dark Tower over the line.
It Comes At Night marks writer-director Trey Edward Shults as a talent to watch.

The Beguiled works primarily due to the casting of Nicole Kidman in the crucial role of headmistress. The star hasn't had a chance to flex her comedic muscles this convincingly since To Die For's wickedly funny Suzanne Stone.
Lady Macbeth is a riveting 19th Century bodice-ripper that also manages to canvas issues of power, class, race and gender politics without labouring any of the aforementioned points.
After eating exhaust fumes for the best part of two hours, this moviegoer left feeling decidedly queasy.
By the time the two travellers have eaten their first proper meal together, Jacques' food obsession is starting to look more like bourgeois self-indulgence.
Bayona shifts easily between the raw, painful reality of Conor's situation and the allegorical fantasies that help him make some kind of sense of it.

Valerian and the City Of a Thousand Planets plays like a psychedelic joy ride through the cinematic universe -- with nods to Star Wars, Blade Runner and Avatar amongst others. But it lacks any kind of narrative compass.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gore's tenacity in the face of so many setbacks is hugely impressive. This is a man for whom the term indefatigable could have been coined.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It has precious few strengths.

Having successfully pulled off three Danny Ocean cons, director Steven Soderbergh is looking for a new bank vault to plunder. Logan Lucky turns out to be a playfully subversive variation on the theme.
As a feel-good romantic fantasy, this grey-powered version of Notting Hill just passes muster. But it's a far cry from the filmmakers' best work.

Annabelle: Creation is a workmanlike horror film that skilfully builds narrative tension and offers horror fans some genuine, well-developed scares. But Sandberg is unable to transcend a stale and rather pedestrian storyline.

Liman, who has already established himself as an action-savvy filmmaker, handles the '80s tonal shift with deft assurance. And he is well-served by Cruise, who delivers his best performance in some time in the lead role.
In a performance that echoes her breakthrough role in Mike Leigh's Happy-Go-Lucky, Hawkins embraces this fiercely independent spirit, broken body and softly-spoken soul.
If this 3D restoration feels a littler leaner and more spare than current blockbusters, that's not necessarily a bad thing. Even in the multiplex environment, less is sometimes more.

[It's] is a pedestrian action comedy with more heavy artillery than it knows what to do with and the plotting is depressingly predictable. But with Reynolds at the wheel and Jackson riding shotgun, it's almost worth going along for the ride.
The film is at its best in the brutish bromance between Thor and the Hulk as they compete for the Valkyrie's affections and the title of the strongest Avenger.
Under even the most cursory scrutiny, The Snowman simply melts.

Frot nails Claire's emotional ambivalence and internal moral struggle. And Deneuve underplays the potentially larger-than-life Beatrice, a woman who lives out of a suitcase and earns her money by gambling, with similar assurance.
The filmmakers have set out to create a genuine sense of danger in this jungle world -- without actually traumatising younger viewers -- and they have got the balance just right.

Garfield employs the limited physical tools he has at his disposal to powerful effect. Foy applies the same poise -- and reined-in emotion -- she exhibited as the young Queen Elizabeth to deal with Diana's extremely challenging situation.

Elio might have come across as a bit of a prat were it not for his flickering, on-the-edge-of-adulthood beauty, which helps to mitigate some of his... actions. His emotional vulnerability in the face of his desire makes him universally accessible.
In All the Money in the World, director Ridley Scott suggests everyone has their price.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In The Commuter, Neeson, like his character, is simply punching the clock.
As an oddly engaging romance, The Shape Of Water floats.

Swinging Safari is so crammed with in-jokes and memorabilia, the quieter moments are almost drowned out... But the film still offers movie goers a distinctive, exuberant, quintessentially Australian experience.
It's the indigenous cast, many of them non actors, who take the film to another level.
Even for a G-rated animated adventure, The Jungle Bunch is fairly tame.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The plotting is predictable and the action sequences for the most part unengaging. Black Panther is a major disappointment.
Many of the women at the screening I attended responded to Fifty Shades Freed as if it were a comedy. Perhaps they are on the right track.
Lady Bird... feels like a watershed moment for female audiences in general, offering mothers a working, warts-and-all screen version of themselves that they actually recognise.
As a tribute, the film is very tender. As a biography, it might have benefited from a more objective point of view.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Game Night pulls off more narrative twists than an Olympic freestyle skier. And like those gravity-defying champions, the filmmakers' timing, preparation, and technical precision makes it all look deceptively easy.
It's the weak, pedestrian storyline that fails to carry the load.

The Greatest Showman's floorboard-shaking, Broadway-belting song and dance routines can't cover for its flat-footed screenplay. Behind the smoke and mirrors lies an empty-hearted whitewash of history.
Downsizing's scaled-down characters, however, still offer a fresh and original perspective on mankind's greatest dilemma.
The Day of the Dead, which spans the full spectrum of human emotions, proves to be an extraordinarily fertile backdrop for director Lee Unkrich and his team.
The Florida Project is a worthy follow-up to Sean Baker's groundbreaking 2015 film Tangerine, also co-written with Chris Bergoch.
Tonally, Suburbicon is very flat... But there's something deeply fascinating about its flaws.
Ingrid might be a certifiable mess, but we still wind up rooting for her.

Disturbing, provocative and timely - the parallels with the cases of police brutality and homicide that fuelled the Black Lives Matter campaign - this immersive dramatisation of events won't let us look away.

Lanthimos and long-time writing partner Efthymis Filippou expertly ramp up the tension until its almost unbearable.They couldn't have pulled it off without uniformly strong performances -- there's not a weak link in the cast.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As well dressed as any traditional period drama, Professor Marston offers a romanticised version of events... But beneath that glossy exterior lies a warm enduring love story that challenges rigid gender roles and the social orthodoxy.
A compelling and concentrated drama that doesn't waste a frame.
It might not be subtle but director Simon Curtis makes his case with impressive narrative economy.
Emily Dickinson is a tough nut to crack, but Cynthia Nixon has the right tools.
Chbosky plucks his audience's emotional heartstrings with the skill of a violin virtuoso.
This bite-sized literary biopic takes a good deal of poetic license with Charles Dickens' story around the time he wrote A Christmas Carol.
The most surprising aspect about this singular movie about a singular individual is its universal entertainment value.
Could this be the moment animated anthropomorphism finally jumped the shark?
A minor disappointment.
De Lencquesaing lends her character an appealing earthiness. De France is good, too, as the tart-tongued medic with an overdeveloped sense of responsibility.
movie_title: Just to Be Sure (Ôtez-moi d'un doute) (2017)
