For Daniel Craig the world of Bond could not be more far away: if his East European accent wobbles at times to Liev Schreiber's more authentic vocal, he looks the part of a man who can both kill and care.
This is not really a stand-alone movie at all. It's more a cheeky long trailer for the new TV series of the same name due to start on the Cartoon Channel on October 3.

The kindest thing one can say is that director Jon Avnet and screenwriter Gary Scott Thompson bought a flatpack version of a thriller and then couldn't follow the instructions. Manuals can be confusing.
The movie falls apart when it tries to explain why Poppy's been sent to this school. And the Spartacus moment at her school "trial" for misconduct is so cringe-worthy you want to die.
By Mike Martin - From the man who made Pan's Labyrinth it's a disappointment.

The Roman Catholicism is not diluted. Brideshead itself seems more like a cold cathedral than a home. And Sebastian's homosexuality is not fudged: he kisses Charles on the lips during one boozy summer. Ben Whishaw embraces an aristocratic camp.
Review by Mike Martin - It looks fantastic, and there is an air of real menace to proceedings, but seems to belong to another age somehow.
Absurdity's a crucial trait of Costner films (The Postman? Message In A Bottle?), so hold the exasperated sigh.
There's a proper debate to be had about the validation of torture in so many films. 'We used to outsource torture,' ex-CIA spy Bryan (Liam Neeson) says, 'but it was unreliable.'
Director Paul WS Anderson has stripped out the satire and black comedy of Roger Corman's 1975 original and left us with just a straight homicidal Grand Prix.
This reminds me of The Simpsons episode where Grandpa Abe rides a bike with no hands proclaiming, "Look at me, I'm acting young!" Then he flies into a grave dig.
The film is persuasive that fascism can take root in any environment. Strong performances all the way.
Colin Firth ... he steams a bit for a change in a tale that's strictly so-soap.
Brazil-based drama directed by Walter Salles that went down well at Cannes this year. Of course, women hardly exist in this macho world.
It's cleverly done with lots of nods to other zombie films. You'll probably catch it on DVD

Mendes' Courbet is all the c-words: clever, cunning, a control freak, cynical; ultimately conformist. Here's another c-word - Cowell, Simon Cowell. Like him, she knows what the public want - before even they know it.
Want some advice? Catch the first 10 minutes of Tropic Thunder and the last 10 minutes and you've got a funny film. The other 87 minutes? Anyone for knitting?

Instead of Deliverance's deep backwoods hicks we have now backwoods chavs who live a life unscrutinised by cops or anyone. Watkins has consumed all those tabloid hoodie tales and regurgitated a horror.
It shouldn't be funny. It has drugs, immature grown men, car chases, guns - even a modern remake of Mary Poppins would get this lot in nowadays. But you'll laugh.
In a post Ab Fab world, The Women is distinctly Ab Blab - an awful lot of nattering that has little edge.
The harrowing final reel of the film earns its 12A rating
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Guy Ritchie's black farce comes with the usual swagger and crazy voltage. The years have now given him coherence, and made him a lot smarter. His IQ has gone up.
The Bangkok cinematography has its moments but falls short of the gritty realism of the original. The whiff of the "exotic" is redolent of Judith Chalmers' banal old TV travelogues.
By the time the disco-dancing, man-eating chipmunks turned up, my mind had turned to the weekend.
By Doug Cooper - It's a quirky, offbeat affair, meandering at times but honest and amusing too.
The story makes little sense - least of all why Charlotte Rampling's Priestess doesn't just treat herself to a few Dalmatians and call herself Cruella De Vil.
It's turning out to be a vintage year for dud comedies - The Love Guru, Get Smart, Zohan. Now we have Step Brothers tripping up on the catwalks of comedy.
Bertino does not try to understand his strangers. His primary interest is what happens - the details of crime - as if the film were a dramatised tabloid.
By Mike Martin - When the DVD box set of Shane Meadows is released this will slot in, but won't be the strongest film in the selection by a long way.
Hiring 50-year-old Madonna to sing out Get Smart's end credits is a nice touch - given the film is one long joke almost as old as the Queen of Pop herself.
Just when you think civilisation may be moving forward a bit (OK, I'm an optimist), another Adam Sandler movie comes along.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One week into 2009 and we already have a contender for worst film of the year.
No film that's 129 minutes long should be called The Express - how about The Sleeper To Oblivion?
Suffice to say that any movie that can pack in an orgy (or the idea of one) in puritan Amish country has some merit.
This is every bit as disastrous as that other jungle-based comedy - when Peter met Katie on I'm A Celebrity.

Maxing the sci-fi elements, Bay brings in 50-odd different robots including two that win my Jah Jah Binks Film Award for comic ethnic stereotyping. Shellshock soon locks in as yet another monster twists out of carnage. Then you stifle the yawns.
Against expectation, Nick Moran's stylised biopic of 60s pop producer Joe Meek is a surprising success - even if it's the great cast that saves the day.
As a lavish spectacle, this historical epic takes us back to the great days of King Vidor or Joseph L Mankiewicz, when sets were framed by incidental stars.
Beneath the raw surfaces of this movie there's a sentimentalism that doesn't strike true. Do adult mates put themselves out the way they do here?
This remake by Dennis Iliadis cost a great deal more than Craven's $100k and in many respects is an upgrade. What it lacks in the shock-of-the-new it makes up for with a more rounded storyline.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Bale's dark mood is infectious - this fourth Terminator is a grim stew of alpha-male theatrics down to the two-day-old coyote dish prepared by a post-apocalyptic answer to Gordon Ramsay.
The False Note might have been a more appropriate title. For director/writer Joel Hopkins's tale of second chances doesn't ring true from start to end.

A movie tomb in which zombiedom is confused with - what's the phrase? - "nuanced performances". Fireflies may be a douche to freshen up the thesp skills of A-listers, but why do we have to suffer for their art?

Crafted sadism is not held back - it's a movie Satan himself might have made if he'd got the funding. Raimi's story weds modern careerism to pagan demonology. The result is a fright-fest with satirical undertones.
Awaydays is a wonderful example of nostalgie de la boue - the "yearning for the mud". The pic wallows in Mersey misery evoked by its music heroes.
Sunshine Cleaning is not perverse for the sake of it: its eccentricities arise from characters whose lives fall outside the life guide manuals.
Ben Stiller's comic setpiece interludes provide the best laughs - his encounter with a goofy, officious security guard called Brandon is particularly good.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Kevin Irwin - Stepping out of the shadows of his X-Men pals, Hugh Jackman's feral mutant gets his own back story - minus a true explanation of his glorious sideburns. It's a knowing foundation for franchise glory.
By Kevin Irwin - Star Trek, the final frontier in nostalgia, a crass ploy for box office kerching or a celebration of sci-fi's most iconic forefather? Well, a touch of all three as it turns out.
Director Oudney's great skill is to play a touch on national stereotypes (that's comedy for you) before delving into the heart of her characters.
Angels & Demons is a film for pilgrim sightseers - marvel at the Vatican's lovely paintings as another corpse turns up.
Viggo Mortensen stars as Prof John Halder - far too handsome for such a part: in life, the bookish are usually ugly as sin, let's face facts.
The film so goes against the grain of seculist and feminist thought that you just have to shrug your shoulders and ask: Hell, is it any good as a movie? Not really.

It's hard to believe that two grown men would be discussing masturbation habits on their second man-date - even so, Segel is credible as a plain-speaking man-boy. And Rudd persuades as a man seeking a boyhood he never had until now.
Not even Nancy Reagan's famed astrologer could have timed it better - the release date of Armando Iannucci's brilliant farce.
McGartland's work saved 50 lives, hence the title. Nowhere is mentioned how many lives he lost. The director's claim that he does not take sides has to be questioned.
One minute Seth is solid enough to stop a speeding 4x4, next he's panicking over an approaching UFO. Such cheating robs the film of tension: we need to know limits to start caring.
17 Again is a triumph of casting genius to rival the Davis/Crawford pairing in Baby Jane.
Kevin Irwin - As cynical exercises in teen marketing go, it's all relatively painless and, whisper it, great fun at times.
Tears will be shed as the promised courtroom drama is displaced by other developments - Joan Cusack almost steals the pic as the lachrymose judge who has lost a young daughter herself.

Public Enemies is like a Bugsy Malone for fashionistas - the actors look like models on a GQ shoot, posing about in dapper suits and toting fake shooters. The brilliant jail sets and Chicago recreations only add to a sense of mannequin perfection for styl

Public Enemies is like a Bugsy Malone for fashionistas - the actors look like models on a GQ shoot, posing about in dapper suits and toting fake shooters. The brilliant jail sets and Chicago recreations only add to a sense of mannequin perfection for styl
Excellent anarchic fun with a twist of psychological truth.
The 60s period detail is spot on, the script super-knowing. A wonderful surprise of a movie.
Because none of the footage here was ever intended for public viewing - only for MJ's library - the film has a unique and welcome authenticity.
Three of the four principal guys in this comedy are well over 15 stone - making them clinically obese by their body mass indexes. They need to lose weight not lessons in "couples skills building."
Terry Gilliam is perhaps the only director who could lure in the late Heath Ledger, Johnny Depp, Colin Farrell AND Jude Law - and still produce a phantasmogoric stinker.
Lovers of therapy-speak with its "closures" and "I'm in a good/bad place" will probably warm to this film.

Visually, Up is breathless perfection, a dream ride of vivid colour and wit. It also has emotional depth. Carl's sense of failed purpose is felt: indeed he and Muntz are both, for different reasons, seeking fulfilment.
Zombieland's not the first pic to take the mick of the genre. This one though has a great deal more zest than most.
Even atheists may smart at the family picnic where a character intones, "All of nature is a battlefield," while neat cucumber sarnies are passed about.

This may not please MTV fans but will appeal to primetime TV family audiences who've grown to expect the slickness of The X Factor's production values. Loads of talent and plenty of pretty faces. What's not to like?

Director Marc Webb's debut feature is as far from a Sandra Bullock or Hugh Grant vehicle as you can imagine. What better reason to go see it? From start to end his subtle movie feather-teases your funny spots: it amazes, refreshes and it delights.

You have to go back to 1979 and the premiere of Alien to find a sci-fi ET movie as thrilling and innovative as director Neill Blomkamp's District 9. His satirical fable on racism delivers all the toys and ploys for the fanboys while teasing and teaching t
Set in war-torn Iraq of 2004, the pic's certainly excellent in many ways. But it never asks the question: "What are these American soldiers doing here?"
A relatively sophisticated comedy - despite the male insecurity fixations - and one that rings true on the oddballs paid to make us laugh.
Dance Flick is a clod-hopping daddy hoofer of a pic that's arrived about a decade too late.

The Dirty Dozen it most definitely is not. It's a war movie like no other, a 21st century film nerd's take on the 20th century's most tragic chapter. Cinderella's slipper and Sherlock Holmes' pipe are among the unlikely delights in QT's best film to date.
We expect a fashion flick to be bitchy, shiny, brittle and superficial. So Coco Before Chanel may give many fashionistas the needle.
There's a docu-drama to be made about movies like this. About how no-one had the courage to tell the star: This ain't funny!
Troma and porn have flogged this sort of stuff for years - the kind of films that don't get previewed by critics.
At the Sandra Bullock Movie Factory, a Hunky Co-Star Assembly Line rivets a new head on a standard male muscular body per SB pic.
Imagine Absolutely Fabulous without Edina and Patsy, or Dynasty without Alexis, and what have you got? The Informers.
Not even the marvellous Sam Rockwell (all two or more of him) can quite make up for the lack of dramatic impetus. You watch it and you keep thinking: Oh no, I can't cope with all this acting!
Jim Broadbent's casting is a master stroke. He captures perfectly that blend of scattiness, eccentricity, furtiveness and fear that makes up Slughorn.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There are sequences of comic genius but you suspect that the huge dollop of cruelty in Cohen has got out of hand - and then the movie wilts.
Ice Age 3 is wittier than Kung-Fu Panda, certainly as slick as Toy Story. The Ice Age franchise shows no signs of thawing out. Come on 4!
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A carbon-rich orgy for eunuchs of the freed speed creed.
Earnest types speak in awe of wave sizes, yet no one once thinks to mount a camera on a surfer for a vicarious thrill. A lost opportunity.
This is a post-9/11 city: terrorism is suspected, the cops are over-armed and trigger happy. Why they don't shoot Ryder when they could is unexplained.
3-D debris (both animal and mineral) fly out of the screen every minute or so. Best wear an apron if you're suggestible.
The Eastwood legend is set against false sentiment, pot-pourried politics. There's no Disney in this Walt.
Jamal Woolard is an inspired piece of casting in the title role, not disguising sweetness behind the macho and arrogant gangsta facade.
The real stars of this movie are not the notice-me dogs or the notice-me-more kids. The stellar pair are failed rock singer Carl Scudder (Kevin Dillon) and his sidekick chick Lois (Lisa Kudrow).
Nispel's problem is that we have seen it all before - Jason's butcherings are well set up, yet films like those in the Saw series have hardened our tums.
This sequel to Martin's dire 2006 not-a-remake requires an autopsy, not a review, to establish cause of death. To start with, Steve Martin simply does not understand Jacques Clouseau.
The ensemble cast includes Drew Barrymore and Jennifer Aniston in what feels like a Friends-style chick flick for the unwise lovelorn.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: With swelling lips to rival Pete Burns's, and long blond locks shorn from Marilyn (the '80s pop singer, not Monroe), Rourke sails above the freak show to give his greatest performance yet.
Great action and witty sight gags raise the toon bar.
Taking a leaf out of Pedro Almodovar's book, Woody Allen makes best full use of Penelope Cruz who's inclined to wilt if not placed in her native Spain.
This is as true to a Marvel comic tale as I've ever seen - gory, serious, intense, dark and utterly psychotic.
Streep, I think, subverts the film's intention by allowing us rightly to sympathise a little with a woman whose power base is under threat by a man.
Thirteen Oscar nominations? You have to wonder at the emotional maturity of the Academy Awards jury - perhaps they, as Pitt's Button, are ageing in reverse and are now sitting on their potties.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is an act of image-exorcism, a preparation for his golden years?
Why the evil-doers need to do what they do is never explained. All we get is an atmospheric soundtrack desperately seeking a horror movie.
The mood of the film is refreshingly relaxed on sexuality. One outbreak of homophobia is quickly punished with a headbutt by a butch boy with no name.
Revolutionary Road is a moany, groany, phoney Oscars contender that's all boo-hoo-hooey. Mendes merely assumes we will share his characters' contempt for 'burbs life.
One measure of Penn's achievement is that the character we get to know surpasses the pink issue. Penn's Milk is a warrior against bigotry.
Demme may be aiming at an inclusive message about the modern balm of family love - it all seems a little forced, emotions regimented by therapy-speak and aching political correctness.
Sheen captures Frost's benign chainsaw whine while Langella is a fabulous baritone monster of alternating self-pity and demonic, forensic guile.
Kevin Irwin - Cruise is stomachable and the production is grandly ambitious, but it's the gripping true story that triumphs as the real star.
Mindless mayhem all the way.
Soon enough, Danny's up there with the skinhead, suggesting his own masculine ego is the priority, not his kids.
Will Smith is fast turning into the movie actor's Reader's Digest - an uplifting guide to healthy living and doing worthy things.
What doesn't make sense is that while the doggies can follow human speech, the humans don't get pooch talk, it's all Yap-Yapanese.
It's all very sex-lite - one character even does what Eamonn Holmes did last year, confusing lesbian with Lebanese.
As films go, it's more like Stars In Their Eyes as you listen in wonder and look for faults in the excellent impersonators.
Why would a psychic 'tec need to sniff a toothbrush to locate its user? Does spearmint freshness have a spooky vibe?
With streets flanked by monster fashion ads, and all the girls looking sublime, Shopaholic is a glam promo for big spenders. Which is a bit ironic.
Goyer's psychic dream sequences are pretty good - what a pity he decided to ruin them with a movie.
The pic will amuse those who don't know much about faith and who like to hear what they think. These people will find the movie so comforting.
Richard Curtis could have cast a more dyspeptic eye on his pirates and still told a compelling tale. But a love of 60s pop has got the better of him.
Slow pace dilutes the few moments of tension. A genre should have been picked and stuck with.
The ending is as baffling as anything preceding it - giving rise to a genre conflict situation.

The theme of treachery is well unpicked as our view of the moral limits of "necessary evils" gets stretched. Only Horn's unlikely visit to a girlfriend and an obscure ending mar a taut, engaged thriller.
Despite fancy writing, it's just another gore porn flick, out to shock for the hell of it and designed for loners who attend film festivals.
Cage is back to form after recent awful films like The Wicker Man and Bangkok Dangerous. Proyas encourages Cage to under-play with conviction. And the result is thrilling.
If I say I was totally won over by this little movie then imagine a vegan praising Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall's hideous slow-braised squirrel dish. It really is that unlikely.
Alan Rickman plays the British wine expert who sponsors the test and is at his most comically feline. It's a great film about passion, eccentricity, families and... wine
It's quite easy: either go get a sedative and calm down, dear. Or see this gentle and frankly boring-as-hell movie.
Men of a certain size will love Paul Blart - and his pursuit through the centre is remarkably inventive. Truly for all the family.

Now that "banker" is a term of abuse, more offensive than any word it rhymes with, Tom Tykwer's film is extremely timely. It has the hard-edged efficiency of The Odessa File - and a sequel would be most welcome.
This British comedy is all Norman and no Wisdom or all Wise and no Morecamble. I have seen Venetian blinds that are funnier.
Postlethwaite's battered face is a good metaphor for Earth's ravagement. But the film is too overtly left-wing and anti-US to be of inclusive use.
A striking feature of the movie is the cool, practical temperaments of the three related female leads. It's a line that adds credibility to a movie of tremendous maturity and restrained passion.
This is not the first movie to have a laugh with the hicks versus city slicks theme - it's a pity director Jonas Elmer didn't add a little acid.
The gothic world of the early scenes promises an adventure that never comes. The style is needlessly impenetrable, yet the theme is simple enough.
Duplicity is one big fogbank of a movie and sounding a horn won't help you. Prepare to get lost in a mass of pointless murk.
What the film lacks is a sense of its awful era - if only Dickens could have had a hand in the script.
Perfectly paced, with the many long silences you get in real life, Kelly Reichardt's film is undone by a fatal plot flaw involving the dog.

Watchmen's rich and gorgeous palette and campy costumes cannot hold you for all of its epic 162 minutes. British Watchmen fanboys probably once read NME and worshipped Joy Division - oh well, Nietzsche to his own.
This is a sadistic film, so be warned.
Belly laughs are few, a sharp script keeps you on your toes. However, Kathleen Turner as a Barbara Woodhouse-style dog trainer, leg-humped by Marley, is a sight you have to see.

Bronson resembles A Clockwork Orange or Jubilee: brutal, arty. Tom Hardy is exceptional, snarling and uncompromising, alert and always impenetrable. We are not asked to pity Bronson, only to spectate at an exhibition of criminal creativity.
Tonderai makes good use of soulless motorway catering venues - all white strip lighting and hunched zombie drivers - but overkills his tale with a succession of improbabilities.
Early scenes, when strange sounds fill the studio and a phone keeps ringing, are creepy enough - but when a hidden message is detected on a track, the film crumbles from tinnitus.
The western genre is defined by its gritty and grimy aesthetic. Fuqua crafts his world with too little tumbleweed and too much Hollywood sheen.
Barry is well paced and doesn't rely on tired biopic tropes to get points across. The film is also really funny.
(re)Assignment is one hell of an ugly film and I'm not just talking about its grimy aesthetic.
Everything about The Headhunter's Calling feels like they took a stock movie script template and didn't bother filling it in.

The film hits the ground running, ratchets up the intensity, and reaches an exhilarating crescendo that is sure to please. Genre movie lovers are going to walk away certain they got the most for their money.
If action, violence, and dark humor sounds like your kind of thing, then get ready to have a blast.
Deepwater Horizon lacks the fun found in big dumb action movies, the suspense found in thrillers, and the emotional heft found in dramas; it just floats in a humdrum middle ground.
The Edge of Seventeen doesn't push the genre in a new direction like Heathers or Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Instead, the film settles into a familiar groove.

Loving is the work of a phenom director firing on all cylinders. The story is both heart-breaking and uplifting; the enthralling production design and cinematography actually romanticize such an ugly era, and the performances can't receive enough praise.
With an exceptional lead performance by Bale and some of the year's most stunning cinematography, Hostiles ruff-and-tumble world is worth visiting.

Buster's Mal Heart isn't a light watch. If you don't make an effort to keep up, the movie will leave you in its dust. Those patient enough to untangle Smith's topsy-turvy narrative structure will find an underlying beauty in her work.
This is not the boxing movie you want to see, it is the boxing film you should see.
Penn's riveting performance commands attention.
It's not Schindler's List, but it's not Catwoman either.
I would have easily escaped, leaving Hawke popping Secondals and thinking about how to dole out the bullets. I'm that kind of woman.
Scary, creepy, mean, and I watched it through my fingers. That said, it is an insult to all of us with Imaginary Friends.
Trite, but, Dermot Mulroney, I took an exit poll. You are definitely worth the extra three hundred.
Smith has another hit, James beats pal Ray Romano to movie stardom, and acting lessons pay off for a supermodel.
Here is a brand new genre: A black-Christian romantic revenge comedy. It doesn't quite work, but Tyler Perry is a jewel.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: An effective claustrophobic nightmare.
A by-the-books Disney family film. If this is what you are looking for, Diesel delivers an easy, goodwill charm. The preview audience embraced it.
Painful to sit through. Except for Travolta & Thurman's dance, this is awful. Product placement everywhere and only Aerosmith's Joe Perry & The Rock keep their dignity.
A little Lovelace and a lot of 85 year olds talking about it. It ain't pretty.
I believe in Satan, Hell, demons walking the Earth, and Keanu Reeves as a cancer-ridden exorcist. Stay until after the credits for a denouement.
Greg Focker is ashamed of his loving parents and Jack Byrnes needs Viagra.
Smug and slow moving. Who cares about Steve Zissou? For Anderson, it is all about the boat.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The balletic battles are pure artistic magic; yet the story exhausted me. How about a simple, straightforward story next time?
Sublime. I loved it. And I'll love it when I see it again.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Should kill the behemoth all-time money-making musical.
We brush past the cruel and harrowing life of the women "in the line."
Scarlett gets a GED and Travolta plays an old drunk with a black toe.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A neurotic wife hires a drop-dead gorgeous, Mexican housekeeper and then insists she spend 3 months in Malibu with the family. Yeah, wives do that all the time.
Ridiculous heist foisted on us by beautiful actors.
Only for Blade fans.
I didn't like it, then I liked it.
A vainglorious valentine, but either act or direct. Please don't do both.
Fantastic! DiCaprio channels Hughes. Scorsese finally breathes life into his muse.
Assured, sophisticated, and confident debut.
Beautiful people's selfish sex lives, tears, and glossy infidelity. Owen and Law weep for Roberts.
A bold, challenging performance by Anne Reid.
An honest screenplay and an unsentimental performance by Bacon.
Joyous fun with a strong, positive Indian sensibility. A beautiful cast certainly helps.
The kid is a high-functioning autistic and the mother is terrified of him. It's not a horror/thriller, just a tedious bore.
Breck Eisner's youthful, fresh grasp of the high-adventure genre. This should have been his audition reel for helming 007/21.
I felt like I was being held prisoner. How could such a daring rescue be so boring?
Super Troopers, Club Dread, and now this. Chandrasekhar cannot be stopped.
A phallic masterpiece. My testosterone level went up 10%.
Michael Bay finally accepts the challenge of an intelligent script. He doesn't screw it up.
Terence Howard has the unique pathos that made John Travolta a star in "Saturday Night Fever."
Hysterical. It is the triumphant return of the R rating comedy (and Ben Stiller is not in it).
Burton and Depp's Willy Wonka doesn't like children. I admire that.
So bad it takes points away from BATMAN BEGINS.
The curse if lifted, but who cast blank slate Katie Holmes? The bottom line is Batman isn't gay anymore but the homoerotic tradition lives on in Scarecrow.
Answers the question: How does a working-class guy handle an alien invasion, destruction of Earth, and disrespectful kids?
See it if you love 3D movies and you are a bullied kid.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Mature and unsentimental. Crowe's commitment to truthful acting triumphs along with Bierko's breakout role as his tormenter.
Simply terrifying. A lesson in undulated shock.
Halfway through, becomes a really funny adult animation film.
Do your hair at home.
If only the ethnic-reassigned Burt Reynolds had stayed naked on that bear rug.
Enthralling and stunning. So it comes down to this: Darth Vader had a selfless good reason.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: I sided with the mother.
A sanitized version that celebrates a surrender. Saladin never mentions Allah. It's not religion, but economy that drove 8 Crusades across two hundred years?
A pre-teen has a homosexual retarded 41 year-old friend and a sexually inappropriate mother. Is this Duchovny's psycho-sexual autobiography?
Preachy about forgiveness but still an intelligent thriller.
Better than the original and scarier than The Grudge or The Ring 2.
Sam Elliott is depressed in New Mexico. I was depressed in Las Vegas watching this film.
Obsessed fans, you've won no converts.
A charming miracle of a family film.
Impressive and intimate look at the realilty of the aftermath of the U.S. invasion of Iraq.
Sublime! Visually stunning. Great, meanspirited fun.
Nice poster.
Stephen Chow's peculiar vision of an action - comedy - musical - drama. For over-the-top excess, this takes pride-of-place.
Costner takes over a Jack Nicholson part and perfectly engages us. Not every middle-aged star needs Tarantino to have a career resurrected.
Do you want to be a celebrity, get free clothes, comp'd rooms, and VIP treatment, or, do you want to be an actor? Kutcher chooses.
Historically accurate (minus one key point) but was Alexander really so weepy? What about his extravagant lust for bloodshed?
Ruthlessly on target.
Okay. It's official now. I hate Christmas.
Stunning and harrowing.
Cruise thrills in his first killer role and has found a worthy collaborator in director Michael Mann.
Spoiler Right Here: Ben Stiller is in the woods.
Carefully structured from 1600 hours of film, yet still an impressive insight into Metallica's world.
Why does our culture loathe the penis?
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Being a superhero has big financial and psychological drawbacks.
This cat doesn't purr.
Audiences love this movie. So do I.
A haunting, serviceable thriller.
Aesthetically dazzling.
It's not a comedy.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Who cares about the toying of a sacred legend? This film works on it's own merits.
Jackie Chan is in a tiny tub with a man. Again.
The Porter's sexless marriage means the film is sexless.
It is a punishing, brilliantly executed indictment.
Your local Pennysaver is more exciting.
Flawed mythology but the entire production is first-rate and visually stunning.
The Potter universe is finally imaged with magical perfection. Any chance Cuarón could re-do HP1 and HP2?
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

Awesome! Breathtaking! Tarantino shows off his libido and his id.
You are going to squirm in Seat 13 of the jury box.
More passion than ever.

Lane captivates the screen with womanly sensuality.

Cage actually inhabits the mind and body of an obsessive-compulsive.
The Creeper really expresses himself far more than his sitting duck victims.
Up-close dentistry, a violent toddler, a family sick with the flu, and non-stop vomiting. That's entertainment!
FRIENDS made her rich; MARCI X should kill her career.

Joyfully subversive. I loved every minute of it.
The sexiest couple alive are really dopes! And Martin Brest proves it!
Farrell and Martinez overflow with testosterone.
More sex, more exotic locations, but still no decent story.

movie_review_blurb: A bloated, slow bore. And I'm being kind.
I've studied Martin Luther. Joseph Fiennes ruins him.
Bruckheimer/Bay creed: If your stars are not killing people or destroying other people's stuff, you are boring the audience!
Keaton apologizes for growing old. Nicholson, at a hard won 67 years old, still expects us to believe 25 year-old models think he's hot.
A disgrace. A spineless eunuch of a father allows his children to yell at him and bully him. They destroy a mansion. Their mother must be on heroin.
Smug comedy.
This remake does not want to annoy us with philosophical trappings. There is no sociological subtext.
DMX is vengeful, mean, and ruthless.
Suspenseful, nail-biting thriller with not enough Olivier Martinez

Engaging thriller laced with uneasy tension.
Kilmer is back in a taut thriller and Mamet uses him to full advantage.
Yeah! Just what we were waiting for: A recruiting film for teen pornography.
Misery wants company.

movie_review_blurb: No. No. No.
A triumphant masterpiece. Is Gibson this millennium's Saint Paul?
Boy-boy love masquerading as boy-girl-boy love so you'll go see it.
Finally, the out-of-the-closet Starsky and Hutch!
Unfunny.
A brilliant, praise-hailing portrayal by Theron. One of the great performances of the past twenty years.
A rude, raunchy teen comedy done right.
Adam Sandler's farewell to movies.
Warning: Story and plot revealed.
Long, ridiculous, and boring.
Not all inspirational stories about sports should be made into movies.
It's like watching [fine art] paint dry.
An insult to the audience while the cast gets a paycheck and an all-expenses paid vacation in Hawaii.
They win. The Publicity Machine has convinced me: Jennifer Aniston can heal the sick!
Outlandish premise. Cleverly executed.
Enchanting.

movie_review_blurb: I sat through it twice. Yes, it is well produced but still panders to a megastar.

The audience laughed at the improbability of the story. This is a bad sign.
Fluff.
Goodbye Meg Ryan.
Forget it.
Erotically delicious.
Awesome! And Johnny Depp's swashbuckling gay pirate mesmerizes!

NARC is gritty, involving, and tense enough to keep audiences riveted and paying close attention.
Ponderous...dismally realized and offers no answers to the puzzle presented.
Oh, James! Your 20th outing shows off a lot of stamina and vitality, and get this, Madonna's cameo doesn't suck!
Sean Penn, you owe Nicolas Cage an apology.
Incredibly, once again, screenwriter Steve Kloves and director Chris Columbus deliver a movie without passion.

movie_review_blurb: ...spellbinding fun and deliciously exploitative.
It's a brilliant, honest performance by Nicholson, but the film is an agonizing bore except when the fantastic Kathy Bates turns up. Bravado Kathy!
Post 9/11 the philosophical message of "Personal Freedom First" might not be as palatable as intended.
Tony Manero, Rocky Balboa, Eminem. It's a dazzling debut and an important movie.
Allen's got a modesty that translates well in this type of story.
After seeing SWEPT AWAY, I feel sorry for Madonna.
Hayek is stunning as Frida and...a star-making project.
Kinnear doesn't aim for our sympathy, but rather delivers a performance of striking skill and depth.
...skillfully directed with flair and personality by George Clooney.
This movie is about lying, cheating, but loving the friends you betray.
It's awful, but a guilty fun time will be had by all.
Writer/director Burr Steers knows how to show irony, the trouble with kids, and New Yorkers taking casual sex for granted.
It's not THE SIXTH SENSE, but close enough.
...wannabe mob sons in a hick town milling around-buying beers and showing off their leather jackets.
Sandler, in trusting his director, gives a performance that declares the star a genuinely fine actor.
I'd have to say the star and director are the big problems here.
[Newton]wanders through CHARLIE completely unaware she needs to show some presence and star quality.
Ratner makes every scene confrontational and eerie.
It's not life-affirming - its vulgar and mean, but I liked it.
I love Reese Witherspoon but hate cruel, dismissive disregard for nice characters. Warning-SPOILER ahead.

Terrible.
Xander Cage-there's a tough little British guy nipping at your heels!
[Hawn's character]is so bluntly written, without a trace of sentimentality, and so blisteringly defined, that every other character seems overlooked and underwritten.
Just dreadful. I don't blame Eddie Murphy but shouldn't Owen Wilson know a movie must have a story and a script?
Connery chews the scenery, beats up everybody in sight, and tries to bully his co-stars into acting.
I'll be the reckless, foolish messenger and endure the wrath of LOTR devotees: Compared to The Fellowship, The Two Towers is a big, sprawling disappointment.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: There's not a comedic moment in this romantic comedy.
Big, tough Arnold, huge product placement, and no clever story. Yet the formula works.
Warning: Spoilers necessary to dope out the stupid story!
Sluggish direction, bad writing, and Lolita Davidovich.
Screaming fun.
Shocking, disturbing, and a daring, electrifying work.
Are there 72 year-old hit men?
Disappointing.
Awesome, and ripe with passion and sex.
Horrible.
Rich special effects, emotional subtext, and wry attitude that deftly out-ranks the original (but Nightcrawler annoyed me).
Appallingly terrible from start to finish.
Delicious con game movie with beautifully crafted characters.
Charming, sweet, and I'm looking forward to seeing all these characters again.
Insufferable. Chow Yun-Fat still needs a good American movie, but is time slipping away?
The problem with ANTWONE FISHER is that it has a screenplay written by Antwone Fisher based on the book by Antwone Fisher.
Terrific performance by Nolte but poorly executed heist.
A taut, engrossing thriller.
A vainglorious performance by Travolta, but so delicious its hypnotic.
Bruno Barreto's lead pipe comedy. Gwyneth, why?
Raw, vulgar, and very, very funny.
...disjointed, silly, and sloppy.
Pure punishment.
An overly sentimental, arch screenplay detracts from Fuqua's previously exhibited strength as a director.
...a bloated, verbose bore. It was pure agony.
Vaughn captures all the attention with his defiant and captivating approach to the material.
The problem with Daredevil is, regardless of the glut of PR hype, Affleck doesn't have sexual charisma. He can't hold the screen - with or without the mask.
It's simply lousy and racist.
Impressively, Lee steps out of his narrow genre, paints a stunning portrait of New York City, and will surely gain a wider audience with 25th HOUR.
...Caine, given the material, manages to convey a degree of self-respect.
The story drags on and the drama only comes to life when the astonishing Day-Lewis is on screen.
A disappointment for Vin Diesel fans. Nothing fresh happens.
Clifford Irving is a villain. Richard Gere makes him charming, but flawed.
Brilliant yet brutal without playing on our guilt. Straightforward horror with an astonishing cast. It is director Steve McQueen's masterwork
Death Proof was sensational. If only Rose McGowan could act.
A boring, editing mess with an absurd jump cut in the action not worthy of a major hoped-for franchise.
If you love the Coen Brothers, don't see this movie. You do not want to go inside Llewyn Davis.
A brave, uncompromised remake of the cult original. It is worth seeing.
Swank takes some time off to vacation in a silly paranormal thriller.
Assange is demonized and the Cumberbitches are going to be enraged.
He hated being famous.
Howard chose the wrong race car driver. Thanks to Hemsworth's natural, easy-going charisma, it is an almost sexy movie with flashes of the lead character's flaws.
After seeing this, you will say: Jackman also plays Wolverine?
A frank, blunt and realistic look at the dark side of life in New York City - for many young men and women.
Diesel has resurrected Riddick and even though I didn't know what the hell was going on, it was terrific.
An extremely engaging sci-fi thriller with a director's strong point of view on the caste system. Should be seen twice.
It's about lost shoes and bloody noses.
A messy magic act dominated by Eisenberg who once again shows off his amazing skill at memorizing long monologues
Stale. Rated "R" for what? Doesn't just end the franchise, Part lll murders it. I laughed once.
Maguire open-mouth stupefaction dominates, Mulligan is miscast, and DiCaprio does his best to save his dignity.
Stupid and messy. The Most Beautiful Woman in the World has to go. Pepper must take "Happy" with her.

Michael Bay delivers a terrific, violent, funny heist movie. Wahlberg once again throws himself into the role without movie star ego. He's fabulous - as it seems - always. I learned a lot about bodybuilders.
Who knew there was a special K-11 inmate division for LGBT criminals to run the dormitory, take drugs, dress up and have sex with the guards?
Convoluted and deliciously twisty but worth even a second viewing. I've been placed under hypnosis and it's not like this at all. Why isn't Vincent Cassel a huge star in the U.S.?
Thrilling, then it goes Hollywood stupid and then the best ending ever! Berry's hair co-stars and chews the scenery.
Jim Carrey walks off with the movie and he knows it.
Morality is flexible and self-interest is paramount. Another terrific collaboration between director and star.
Tina Fey's first big blunder. Cavalier and flippant regarding serious issues. Sloppy directing, terrible acting. Where is Helen Hunt when you need her?
Fee-fi-fo-fun! Singer has cleverly re-interpreted the fairy tale saving Jack's reputation.
He's not back yet.
New Yorkers would never elect a man for mayor who wears bangs.
It's Paddy Chayesky's Marty drenched in silent emotion.

Long, cheesy political monologues and crucifies the Lincoln legacy. What a torture! Director Steven Spielberg and screenwriter Tony Kushner turn the hallowed figure of Abraham Lincoln into a dreary sop.

Skyfall keeps mocking 007 as old and out-of-touch. He goes unshaven and fails his physical! The ice-cold erotic charge of an immaculately groomed Bond is dead. Fleming's 'blunt instrument' has bad knees. He's one of us now.
A comedy with silly music, long patriotic speeches, ham-fisted acting and the villain is Hitler's signature.
Air travel rules and regulations pushed aside, Neeson is totally committed to the role.
Raw, daring, provocative and perfect von Tier. Eagerly waiting for Volume II.
Based on the Hindu caste system. Is there anyone in this movie besides Theo James? He's so sexy he makes Vampires and Tributes look like sissy-girls.
Michael Mann has made some good movies. This is not one of them.
Another Tim Burton fairy tale. Adams and Waltz miscast. The screenplay is shallow and has no depth. The ham-fisted acting doesn't help.
If you support your family picking lettuce, your life is more interesting than Linklater's family.
A powerful and challenging film with a great deal of psychological symbolism. If it's a hallucination or alternate universe experience is up to you.
A stunning performance by Cotillard and a moral dilemma aptly presented.

Hollywood biopics infantilizes its audiences. If someone's true story ended badly, it's a text epilogue that tells us what happened. When Hollywood does another biopic of Jesus's life they will leave out the crucifixion.
Carell is mesmerizing but nominations should also go to Tatum for an equally vanity-free performance. The acting succeeds while the story lacks a more in-depth study of a very complex relationship.
Would be a peerless film if Clint Eastwood kept to Kyle's fascinating military career and left out the annoying, under-written personal story.
A sweet fairy tale of the marriage between a living legend, anti-God "saint" and the wife who attended to his every need. A nice whitewash. It's not a warts-and-all film.
WHIPLASH offers Simmons a truly grand opportunity to be the vilest character of the year.
Dazzling, frightening and thrilling. Pure cinematic magic. But the philosophical points presented - love and survival - are contradictory.
There should be nominations and awards for all involved - Best Picture, Director, Actor, Supporting Actress, Supporting Actor, Screenplay and Cinematography.

The brilliant frontrunner of the genre. Hail the return of Reeves back on top in this exciting "kill-them-all" aria. The soundtrack is fantastic. Keanu, stay with this franchise and away from romantic movies.
It's his Watergate. He has a "Deep Throat". Terrific thriller with a great performance by Renner but fails to bring the family's lives to life.
At best, Butler (as the Mr. Miyagi of surfing) got to learn how to surf from a professional.
Luke Evans puts sexual energy and masculinity into the legend. It's dark, moody and I'm ready for the sequel.
Thankfully, its true to the book. Fincher faithfully captures the cruel dynamics of a ruined marriage. If only we saw why these two people hated each other.
Unrealistic premise that drags on.
This sequel has girth. The filmmakers got the magnificent unclothed Eva Green as cinema's deadliest femme fatale but Jessica Alba gets star billing?
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: I want more Tammy. I want the franchise, the book, the FX series and the musical.

A sloppy, lazy, energy-free back lot production. Everything is wrong except the music. The dreadful "dee's," "dem's" and "does" are as shameful as the clumsy acting. Eastwood proves he has limitations.
Pattinson transcends his career-strangling straightjacket with a dynamic performance - don't go back now! Does Guy Pearce ever make a wrong step in picking films?
Terrific. Best of the summer. Cruise oozes charisma and has real chemistry with Blunt.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Wait for Ted 2.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "The awful thing about life is this: Everybody has their reasons." Maleficent has a very good reason. Sensational Jolie creates the character's evolving emotions purely with her face.
Swinton and Hiddleston are sensuous creatures giving depth to the vampire hagiography.
Fun, not cheesy and reinvigorates the iconic monster.
I loved it. Dazzling, erotic and electrifying. Johansson is fantastic and the mood and music thrilling.
Another von Trier masterpiece. Brilliant, strange, provocative and unsettling. All the characters are just aspects of von Trier - and so is the audience.
A supernatural thriller with the return of the long-lost Steven Bauer!

Every wife of a serial killer is clueless? I doubt it but A GOOD MARRIAGE is terrific. Directed by Peter Askin, it is wildly tense and at times funny. The bravo performance goes to a sexy, hysterical Allen.
Matthew Fox is terrifying and awesome while Perry proves he cannot act, especially in emotional close-ups. I did like the phantasmagoric story
Homoerotic obsession with a very dangerous man. Hoffman plays a seductive, likeable Master. I remember the Lifespring cult in the 80s.

As Fox Mulder's poster proclaimed, "The tooth is out there" applies here, or is that the leap-off for the sequel? It's scary and real. I know two people with similar experiences with spirits contained in non-living objects.
A brilliant, harrowing performance by Bale.
Feral woman meets a lawyer/monster.
It's a remake disguised as a prequel. A very good remake.
What's next? A movie about people watching TV?
The story twists beautifully and shockingly. The ending is brilliant. Skillfully directed by Jordan Scott.
The parents always know.
After watching MGP I forgive Butler his Hollywood rom-coms. Who knew an American could go to the Sudan, kill lots of rebels without any consequences, and become a living legend?
Just awful. Didn't I see this movie in 1987 starring Sylvester Stallone?
Clooney triumphs as a director. The script is acid sharp and the cast perfect.
Jason Statham (or his stunt doubles) demolishes two men while duct-taped to a chair. The entire movie has that kind of action.
A middle-aged couple ignite a firestorm of eroticism.
It's a grindhouse mess but it stars Rutger Hauer!
Brad Pitt makes me almost like baseball. He's endearing and insists on looking his character's age.
Implausible, weak characters with wonky motivations, and a skinny chick who instigates the carnage.
Depp plays a real person but is just a sleepwalker in a meaningless dream. What happened to acting? How about an interesting story?
A silent psychopath with a heart of gold.
Disgruntled teen golfer meets the Yoda of golf. Learns how golf is a metaphor for Buddhism.
The twists are shocking and mesmerizing. A high wire, intelligent espionage thriller. It is one of the best movies of 2011.
Clever and packed with smart characters.
O'Connor has established Hardy as a star and successor to a young, intense Marlon Brando. Hardy gives so much emotion and commitment to every character he plays, that he is a dazzling revelation.
The writer/director/star is enchanted with herself. I hated the cat.
The motion-capture technology is fantastic. The reboot is worthy and I'm looking forward to a long franchise.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Rooted in reality and without the superhero tights, an impressive 3D success. The CGI transformation of Steve Rogers is fantastic. I worry that Stan Lee, through his Hickcock cameos, will appear in perpetuity in all Marvel movies.
...and Indians, peyote, a kid, a girl, and the dazzling masculine energy of Daniel Craig. Highly original and takes this summer's pride of place.
Enthralling and very disturbing.
Astonishing and moving.
Hanks sabotages his and Roberts careers with this lazy, stupid disaster.
The 3D is sensational. Michael Bay delivers on his promise to the fans. The rest of us? Bay doesn't care about us.
I burned off a weekend in Hell sitting through this. What is Adolphe Menjou doing in this? I hate the color green now.
It's the love story of Charles and Erik.
I didn't care about any of the characters, especially happy-go-lucky Patient Zero.
A girl from the "projects" would rather stay put than be the hereditary Queen of a bunch of planets including Earth. Reincarnation gets a slap in the face. The reconstituted Queen hates her kids.
To accurately and intelligently follow ANONYMOUS, you need a copy of Burke's Peerage.
Olsen gives a riveting, challenging performance. A taut psychological thriller.
McConaughey eviscerates his rom-com/MAGIC MIKE legacy with an astonishing, terrifying performance. Makes Frank Booth and Max Cady look like the choir boys of seduction. Friedkin is back!

Nolan created a nihilist anthem. He dumped Batman gadgetry. Makes every past superhero movie look like a boy's backyard staging of Star Wars. Bane takes the movie. Nolan plays to Bale's need to get badly beaten up.
All hail the screenwriters who turned around a rotting franchise by bringing forth a troubled superhero and his conflicted nemesis. The love interest failed.
Horrible. No story, overt homoeroticism, and the death-knell for McConaughey. Is this the same director who did the fabulous HAYWIRE?
Brilliant, brilliant, brilliant! Yes, Abramovic is a seductress.
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Weak fluff but a devastating looks at no-talent celebrities. Only the harried, suddenly anointed celebrity tale was beautifully crafted satire.
All hail mesmerizing Tom Cruise as Stacee Jaxx. There is way too much Hough and Boneta. Baldwin and Brand are the new "yes".

Fassbender's David is the film's centerpiece. Rapace plays the Hollywood girlfriend role instead of a steely protagonist on a messianic journey. Theron always commits fully to every character she plays.

Pretentious, self-serving vehicle glorifying Marling. If you can't get hired, write yourself a role where you are worshipped. Make sure you are the only good looking woman in the film with plenty of golden close-ups.
Finally, Johnny Depp's first hot sex scene. He's got real chemistry with Eva Green. Makes you wonder what happened in The Tourist.
I've been to Rwanda. I have a strong perspective on the genocide.
Two spitting scenes in 3D and Jack Dawson loses his virginity. A second look indicates a cruel streak in the modern epic.
Westfeldt's sloppy love letter to herself and corralled Hamm's friends to help sell it.
A brilliant debut written and directed by Jolie. She has an artist's eye, strong personal vision, and a masterful command of her stars.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: DiCaprio astonishes. It is a revelation. Eastwood directs another sad love story but leaves his hackneyed, over-used score behind.
Ignore the CIA agent gone rouge-laded story. Director Daniel Espinosa delivers a tense, Bourne-style action thriller with bold city streets car chases and messy, bloody fights in hallways.
Madonna's second feature film establishes her as a director, but her sticking to the official myth is laughable. It never bothers to answer the haunting question, "Why Wallis?"
Puts you on the ledge.
The perfect heir to Ripley. Fassbender's scenes give the movie an alarming erotic jolt. You actually believe this woman can fight a man and win.
Fiennes' modern interpretation is absolutely brilliant. There is pronounced homoeroticism and mother-fixation.
Tense, high speed action but with terrible acting, especially Ribisi and J.K. Simmons.
"We're still blaming mothers." - Joyce Flint, Jeffrey Dahmer's mother.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A comedy? Lazy, tedious Polanski. It's all about putting on and taking off coats. Moviegoers will not rush out to the theater after seeing this.
Best line of 2011 delivered by Jeremy Renner: "That's it. Next time I get to seduce the rich guy." Why is MI4 so terrific? I screamed out in the theater: "The pants are gonna rip!"
I hated the kid.

Fincher's Twilight-like Hollywood heroine is shy and moody. Not the venal, alternate lifestyle lesbian-punk hacker from the beloved book. Anybody else think Mara's sex scenes with Craig were done by a body double?
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sex and incest. Michael Fassbinder electrifies. Unfairly an NC-17 movie.
Very clever and highly enjoyable.
Has Ellroy's stamp of living through and surviving decadence. Harrelson expresses a bounty of hostile and rage-filled emotions.
To understand von Trier one must accept Gregory of Nazianzus's explanation of the ascetic doctrine as "the pleasure of no pleasure."
Stands above the rest in the "found footage" genre. I want more.
A huge disappointment. Not funny.
A wimpy, wounded billionaire sadist - correction "dominant" - with a cleanliness fetish and no friends stalks with gifts a passive-aggressive virgin.
Let's hope this slips away before everyone realizes that terrific hot chick from The Wolf of Wall Street stars in this. Will Smith goes through it looking angry at his agent.
Fascinating thriller by a director who understands tension, isolation and uncontrollable fear.
No matter how the "fairy tale" really happened. Some unknown named Gal Gadot was chosen for instant stardom. And she deserves it! Director Patty Jenkins was finally released from Hollywood jail.
The money is on the screen, Captain Jack is still a drunk and Bardem creates another infamous villain. Jack is not gay anymore.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There is a world war going on but people still want entertainment.
The best sequel in years. Though I didn't understand the plot or the dialogue.
The ultimate shoot-out with highly original characters.
A howler of a mess. "Scowling face" hasn't masqueraded touchy-feely homoerotic subtext since FAST AND THE FURIOUS 2.
Terrific performance by Stewart but she needs a better script next time.
Bravo. The film is interesting, controversial and the ending perfect.
Watson is woefully miscast. She has no charisma and does not seem to enjoy being the much beloved fairy tale heroine.
One of next year's nominees for Best Actor must go to Jackman. His Logan is as moving and complex as dramatic characters demand. Boyd Holbrook is a charismatic villain.
Uncovers the extraordinary facts regarding this highly unusual phenomenon. Kitei, a medical doctor, brings a scientist's approach to the subject.

An embarrassment. Billionaire crybaby "sadist" Mr. Grey refuses to be touched. Which means in this fairy tale fellatio is verboten. Anna never praises his instrument. There's no penis idolatry in Mr. Grey's Red Room.

Yes, it's terrific. We have a new Hannibal. Extraordinary performance by McAvoy. It's his next franchise. Will the next 10 years going to be all about Shyamalan all the time? Does he remember his last films with shame like we do?
Keaton straddles the humble, and then the bastard, Ray Croc, with aplomb. You will end up hating the man.
Verhoeven is back thanks to the magnificent performance by Huppert. She deserves the Best Actress Academy Award for her fearless performance.
Brilliant. My choice for Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actress, Best Cinematography, Best Screenplay and even Best Hair. This is Tom Ford(TM)s La Cte Basque, 1965.

It's constant blowing stuff up. Jyn Erso is STAR WARS "Joan of Arc" without a zealot's fervor or dynamic leadership presence. She is the only female fighter and all the nomad soldiers blindly follow her. What happened to Mendelsohn's face?
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Affleck puts his heart and soul in this role.
Avoids sloppy sentimentalism and gives the most probable contact with other beings we will likely encounter.
Doctor Strange rules the Marvel Universe. A fully realized character with dimensions. Bravo to the thousands who created the astonishing visuals.
Astonishing return of Mel Gibson.

Honest and realistic exploration of one man's journey from a neglectful childhood to adulthood and finding his own - highly personal - way in the world. The main character happens to be black and gay.
Jack Reacher may be cinema's reigning street-fighting ascetic.
Entrancing, evocative and a brilliant management of chaos. Sasha Lane is sensational. LaBeouf and Keough are mesmerizing.

If you envy the staged, make-believe life of the Kardashians, you will understand the premise. Blunt, Bennett, Evans, Ferguson and Theroux are sensational. Especially Bennett. If you loved the book, this delivers.
It's Snowden's version of events skillfully directed by Stone who once again knows who the real enemy is.
Tom Hanks suffers and is scared.
Terrific and highly entertaining. Its a smart, aggressive thriller. Luke Scott has arrived.
Under Coppola's direction, eroticism is replaced with female unity and empowerment. Farrell seductive charm is ignored.
Edgar Wright put a YA storyline into a heist plot. Unfortunately, sweet Elgort - a criminal - has no dark edges. Baby has 8 out of 10 symptoms of Asperger's Syndrome.
Sensational. A fully realized, fascinating world. The best film of 2017...so far.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A female driven thriller about a subject very much in the news.
Too implausible, too convoluted to be a serious thriller but Neeson is all in and director Collet-Serra has obvious talent. But who can dope out the plot?
With a bloated 2 hour, 15 minute running time, Coogler ran out of ideas.
Review proof. Padded story with an inoffensive screenplay, stunt casting and, dare I call it, boring.
Enthralling and unforgettable. Yet, reenforces society's belief that the penis is ugly. Could physically gifted Armie Hammer has an ugly penis?
They ticked off all the boxes except the one marked "Jar Jar Binks." You are very old if you needed to see all these characters again.
A stunning performance by Robbie that should gain her a Best Actress nomination. Who could beat Janney's fearless, cruel performance in the Best Supporting category?
Atmospheric thriller from the great Ridley Scott and the perfect Getty - Christopher Plummer. Its his movie. He dominates it.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Reminds me of Pablo Picasso. Brilliant in its savvy cruelty. Day-Lewis delves deeply into his character's psyche. Best Actor of 2017!
What's next? Bringing back Charlie Chan? MURDER lacks ugliness, spite and callousness. Branagh talks too much.
Woody Allen's BLUE JASMINE and now WONDER WHEEL explore his obsession that women are Judases, harming the people closest to them.
Cate Blanchett is Marvel's new goddess and deserves her own franchise. This is the best of the Avengers and Hemsworth's charisma shines throughout, after all, he is the God of Thunder.
Brilliant, unusual thriller by a masterful director.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Frankly, today, what six-year old do you see walking around without a parent? Social Services would be called immediately.
An important look at the man who influenced and structured American civil rights laws.
Terrific and unsettling horror-thriller. Alvarez is using film to explore his fetishes and he's doing a great job.
Impressive and dazzling and takes nothing away from the iconic original.
Emma Stone is dazzling. She is more Billie Jean than Billie Jean.
